39109190.review:
Конечный вывод: рекомендую. Далее объяснения почему минус. Он не случайно.

Отличная игра. Вспомнил потраченные 10 лет на каждодневную игру в Rollscage 2 пока тошнить не начинает. Играл как маньяк только в нее и не мог оторваться. Увидел GRIP. Запрыгал от счастья "Вот оно! Неужели я нашел то, что искал долгие годы?! Неужели я получу то, чего мне так не хватало??". Так вот. Эта игра про это, но далеко не полностью.

Коротко о проблеме: игра очень интересная и улучшенная версия старой доброй гонки. Но в ней есть одна большая проблема, которую надеюсь в будущем поправят разработчики. В ней нету развития, нету компании, все открыто изначально, все бонусы доступны сразу. Помните, как вы, фанаты RC2, впервые открыли ту самую игру? 200Mhp максимум, пара бонусов и делай с этим что хочешь. Потом взрывы 5-ой точки в чемпионатах, прохождение потных карт, открытие машин, бонусов, скоростей, повышение накала и напряжения....ууух...игра очень хорошая, но отсутствие хоть какого либо развития, которое в конце, после всех мук, которые ты переносишь в чемпионатах, позволяло насладиться игрой полностью и наслаждаться ей изо дня в день. Этого ощущения не хватает. Игра цепляет, но не держит, потому что пока что в ней нечего делать. Просто аркада. Как будто ты загрузил чей-то сейв с полностью пройденной игрой. 

Вывод: очень рекомендую...хотя бы к ознакомлению, но ставлю минус, потому что не удержали в игре.
39109190.developer_response:
Привет!

Спасибо за обзор. Окончательная версия будет иметь полную кампанию с турнирами, а также систему прогрессирования с разблокировкой автомобиля и гаража. Поэтому, надеюсь, мы получим положительный отзыв;)

38642842.review:
I loved rollcage on the playstation, it was super fun and creative. This is a good "start". I quote as it's been 2 years almost, I decided to pick this up and it seems competant but there's too many issues for me right now. 

Firstly it's packed with invisble walls I bounce off. This isn't a big problem but in tighter spaces it's not so much that I lose control but that I've jumped a big portion of the race, without any input which sucks. I'd of liked a campaign, even something simple, each track with a medal, just for a sense of progression. It goes too fast and doesn't suit the scale, at least I feel, rollcage felt more elegant because the restrictions of the technology. Slower and smaller is better. Finally, I hate the term "inspired", it's a direct copy. Which is fine, I'm glad they're doing it, I just hope that in time they'll do it properly.

I intend to keep up to date with this, if you're interested I'd reccomend you follow the development and buy it when it's a bit more complete.
38642842.developer_response:
Hi there,

Thanks for you review, there are some points in there that we feel we ought to address.

The invisible walls you shouldn't encounter too often in normal racing and are designed simply to keep you close to the racing track and not have you going off exploring parts of the world that you're not supposed to be in. In this regard, it employs the same techniques that Rollcage did, only less stringently.

Campaign mode is coming with the full game, and we'll be launching later this year

At the end of every game you play you're presented with your personal statistics about the XP gained within the game and how this has affected your current player level. We even give you a ton of game stats that show how you did within the game compared to everyone else. This should give you a fairly solid sense of progression as you get more experience within the game, but we'll be adding more to progression in general

As for speed, simply choose which engine power you prefer in the game options to match the level of speed that you're looking for.

We hope this information tempts you back into the game in order to give it a 2nd chance.

Regarding the Rollcage similarities of course there are many and GRIP was always designed to be its spiritual successor. However, we do have players on either side saying it's too much like Rollcage and conversely it's too far removed from Rollcage. We're trying hard to get the balance right and hopefully arrive at something very new that captures effectively everything that made Rollcage great. Of course, this is impossible without it looking a lot like Rollcage.

38543397.developer_response:
Hi there,

Thanks for you review - we feel there's a couple of points there that we ought to address.

The charging system you mention is not mandatory and not even an essential part of the game. Use it or not, your choice. In essence, it was designed for player's mastery of the game rather than being required to play the game. It was designed to allow you to hit your opponents hard, but only after you've paid a price for that ability. The price, is the drop in speed, which is a choice you have to make. It also quite visibly shows how hard you wanted to hit your opponent and as such helps to promote rivalry within the game.

Holding down buttons shouldn't be a problem as master players will be charging their pickups when they need to reduce speed instead of using the brake. At these times, you're not boosting so don't need to hold that button down simultaneously.

The idea for the charged turbo or Firestorm was that reducing your speed in order to receive a charged Firestorm made no sense at all. So instead, we decided to not slow you down while charging that particular pickup and then give you a ton of boost, but you had better be ready to handle it and use it wisely. In this respect, the wheelies were very intentional as this of course hampers your steering so challenges the master players in using it well. We're not going to give you that much speed for free now are we? You have to be selective and tactical when using this particular charged pickup.

The game in general is no slower than it was beforehand. The only concession we made was making the uncharged Firestorm less powerful than it was before in order to balance the charged and uncharged versions of it. We have since boosted it back up a fair bit during the last 1.2.8 build due to player feedback.

We hope this answers some of your concerns and explains the direction of the game more clearly.

38126640.review:
Imagine Mariocart, just less Mario and more Rollcage.
For an early acces game its pretty refined. Only a single crash ever, because I switched Virtual 7.1audio drivers mid game.

The only thing I´d fix is that alt-tabing doesnt seem to work too well and may freeze your Desktop forcing you to shutdown via windows button and arow keys.

What I like most would be the sheer amount of custom options:
-Custom music you can add.(original music can be disabled by track, or all ot once)
-ANY Graphical option you could think off (if you exclude instagram filters).
-SPLITSCREEN Vertical and Horidontal (Devs if you read this 4 player would be incredible).
-Track mirroring and reversal.
-Multiple weather scenarios for each track.
-Each chassi has multiple rim and tire options and full color customisation.

Driving needs some getting used to as you drive a jet powered car, in air controls are a bit wonky but manageable(I really hope for a seperate thruster control set in the air).

Weapons are also picked up in Mariocart fashion and since the latest update can be charged (reduces your speed temporarily) to extend the damage.

They include:
-A small missile salvo (Unguided)
-A forcefield pushing others away.
-A shield defending your rear end.
-A single fire lock on missile.
-A mine.
-Afterburner
-Machineguns
-A time warp, that slows everyone down but yourself
-As well as a missile that auto locks to the first place player, effectively a blue shell.


Races come in: 
-Time trial
-Last man standing (eliminating the last player every 30 seconds)
-Combat (kills and damage earn you points to victory)
-Classic race, 1st to cross the finish line wins

They can be filled with up to 20 bots and last up to 20 laps.

Graphically the game looks amazing for an indie game without a big publisher behind it.

I cant say too much about performance as I have a 1080ti and a Ryzen 5 1500x ,but my old AMD vision x4 laptop barely plays it. (granted that even portal 2 wont pass 40 FPS on that)


If its on sale and you like mariocart I would give it a shot. Át full price you should watch a letsplay to determine if its worth it for you.

37963762.review:
Some adrenaline pumping, drum and bass blasting, machine gun and missile shooting, roll cage racing goodness. 

It's still in Early Access so there are gonna be some bugs with some of the crazier maps. Every now and then you'll drive over a pebble and go flying wildy into the air. Sometimes you'll hit a barrel in the middle of the road and stop dead in your tracks. If you get turned around the arrows showing you which way to go can sometimes straight up lie to you and have you turn nearly 360 degrees. That's GRIP at its worst.

But when the game is working at its best, a 10 minute race will feel like 3 minutes. You'll be totally immersed in the race. When you pick up a speed boost, be prepared to let Jesus take the wheel. Watching your missile take flight and slam into the car in front of you, then dodging it as it crashes against the course is just so satisfying. Check out some gameplay to decide if this game is for you, but chances are it is and you won't regret the purchase.

4/5

Non so se vi ricordate la Games Machine, la rivista di videogiochi che ci facevamo comprare dal papà solo per il CD con le demo dei giochi, ecco da li ho conosciuto e amato Rollcage, si parla di quasi 20 anni fa, nel 2000.
Oggi, spulciando i giochi su steam trovo questo GRIP e qualcosa mi è tornato alla mente, appena l' ho cliccato e ho visto che era praticamente un omaggio a Rollcage l' ho acquistato praticamente all' istante.
Per chi come me ha consumato il gioco o la demo sà di cosa si parla, un gioco di corse su auto futuristiche che usano la velocità per rimanere incollati alla strada, che sia verticale, orizzontale ecc.
Sono presenti anche i potenziamenti come armi, scudi, EMP ecc (ammettetelo che anche voi siete stati colpiti dal missile che colpisce solo il primo, lo sparavate quando eravate in testa e poi tornava indietro ahahah)
Tra le varie modalità al momento ci sono attacco al tempo, corsa, eliminazione e corsa con le armi, anche il multi è presente, sia split screen che online di cui al momento non ho trovato partite ma è più che comprensibile, stanno ancora sviluppando il gioco.
Possiamo da subito usare i vari modelli di vetture e personalizzare vernice, colore dei cerchi e prenumatici.
Il gioco non ha ancora nessuna modalità o obbiettivi da seguire se non quello di giocare e divertirsi con quello che offre il gameplay che comunque non è poco, è frenetico e molto divertente.
Ho voluto fidarmi del progetto e l' ho comprato, aspetto nuovi aggiornamenti!
Speriamo mettano anche la modalità singola quella che era su Rollcage in cui dovevamo arrivare alla fine di percorsi difficili sfruttando la verticalità e la velocità, come fossero puzzle ad alta velocità, nella demo non ho mai completato quel livello, magari mi rifaccio :D

36314441.review: I would rate this 4 out of 10. The graphics are spot on and look stunning. But the gameplay feels contradictory. You have extremely fast vehicles going around on an open track. You know what that causes? Discomfort. Its just annoying to have the vehice caught on a silly little "bumb" and have it fly off in a random direction. It encourages learning the tracks by heart rather than trying to encourage instinct as most similar racing games do. If you want players to dodge and avoid a crate or a clif or a flag post, give them decent breaking and tight low speed cornering. If you want them to juke, jump and wallride give them large tracks with obstacles that are extremely well defined. Story wise, the "cars have extreme downforce" makes no sense becuase they don t feel like it. They feel like a barrel could shoot them in the air at 60°. The jump.mechanic feels clunky and seems to rely too much on the slowmo. Yea you can get better and better and stop using slo mo, but that is by learning the maps not by improving your skill. As a result gameplay quickly looses interactivity. You guys are so close. The weapon system feels well done, rewarding planning over flick movements. I suggest either making jump instantaneous at full velocity, or removing it completely. Remove slo mo and force players into training towards a fast paced gamestyle. The engine power option is amazing. Or at least it feels like it. Make tracks larger, wider for more movement and decision options. "Do i shoot? Do i steer? Do i break?" Make all these be 33% valuable each and make the responses faster towards these goals and i am sure the gameplay would be legendary. Do not punish players for hitting an object, a pole from a damn bridge. You already have "force walls" in the game why not center the gameplay around a fast tubelike structure instead.of silly "hit the entrance" games. Collisions do not help either. Turning a vehicle 180° only to have the player turn it back and slow to 0 is just not fun in a massive velocity based game. Reset should be rarely needed and not a "cheat ability" as it is now. I hope this helps. Your game has amazing potential and i believe with some tuning around what i mentioned you could really outdo nitronic rush and perhaos become he racing staple of the past 2 decades. Just focus on players having fun rather than "tryharding" and it should work miracles. I do.not regret buying this game one bit and love coming to it every 2 3 days for a few races. Would recommend. Especially if you buy it with a friend.

35206778.review:
Can't believe I haven't left a review on this yet!!

In short, GRIP is fantastic. I've had the game from very early on when it only had three tracks and one car, and even then I could see this game was going to be great. The basic fundamentals of the game felt right, the physics, momentum, speed and looks all came together so well, though minor quirks and issues were present. Over time this experience has improved tenfold. For instance, in earlier incarnations of the game it was far too easy to go airborn from the most minute pebble and lose control, flying from barrier to barrier once launched. This has been addressed, with impacts causing less ricochet and a general smoothing out of the handling mechanics. This includes drifting of vehicles, which is now far more intuitive and less of a cloth touching exercise. The amount of content in the game has increased substantially since I first bought it too, with tons of new tracks and vehicles having been added along with multiplayer finally getting put into the mix. 

The graphics are amazing. It is a modern game through and through, with some great post processing effects and highly detailed vehicles. The textures for the circuits themselves are decent enough and considering the speed at which you go flying through them you will barely pick up on their finer details. The game runs smooth for me, though I have had the chance to run the game on a Fury X and 1080, so am unsure on slightly less powerful cards. However considering the flexibility of the graphics settings and the way the game is optimised already, I feel it should run well on pretty much any modern dedicated graphics hardware.

The cpu difficulty is sufficient and provides a moderate challenge on it's hardest setting and it's highest speed, although this is highly dependant on your start and how well you've mastered the basic mechanics. If you manage to get away well from the start and distance the opposition, it's not overly difficult to go on and win the race. Even then, if you have a decent grasp of the physics of the game and understand where the best lines are then you usually stand a good chance of winning regardless of how well you start. I suppose this is only a minor gripe and will be polished up as the game reaches it's proper release.

One of the additions I was very happy in seeing was the vehicle customisation option which was added into the game. This lets you choose the base chassis, with lots of different variants with different stats, and then decide your colour scheme for wheels and body aswell as choosing from a number of different tyre designs. It's not a huge change but it's a great addition that will likely see fleshing out in the future. 

This game is a great homage to arcade racers dating all the way back to F Zero. It may specifically target those fond of the rollcage games, but it easily scratches the same itch that fans of Wipeout and other similar titles play these games for. It's a riot.

34892320.review:
Rollcage was pretty much my childhood, and I think the squee when I learned this was on its way might have deafened everyone on my street.

[h1]How does it look?[/h1]

GRIP goes for a somewhat 'realistic', gritty visual style and I'd say it pulls it off quite well. With races playing out across a wide variety of sci-fi settings, it manages to make them look pretty convincing. Though you can spot some less-than-incredible textures if you stop and scrutinise every rock or building, in motion everything looks glorious. Wheels kick up dust or snow where applicable, missiles create very satisfying fireballs and damaged cars leave a spectacularly excessive trail of flame in their wake. The car designs of course take their basis from Rollcage, with wheels taller than the body. A lot of effort has gone into making them look more believable, with most wheels actually floating off the axle - a blue glow implying some magnetic trickery going on.


[h1]How does it sound?[/h1]

In keeping with the aim of replicating the feel of classic racers, the soundtrack is primarily made up of drum 'n' bass from contemporary artists, and it works extremely well. There's a good variety of pieces, though they're randomly selected at the start of a race - meaning they're not specifically designed for or matched to any particular ingame track or environment. Regardless, it's good listening and fits the game perfectly. Sound effects are a mixed bag. On the whole everything works, some effects are excellent - you really feel it when an assassin missile impacts for example. However, a lot of sounds - including important things like some of the cars' engines - are placeholder thanks to the game's early access nature. One car's engine is often barely audible, while the recently-added inbuilt boost sounds somewhat pathetic when activated. There are some really nice touches though, such as echo effects when passing through cave areas.


[h1]How does it play?[/h1]

As a whole, Grip can feel quite sluggish at times. A conscious decision has been made to give the cars the feeling of a lot of weight, which is fair enough. Unfortunately that means acceleration can be painfully slow and turning tends to have a lot of understeer, leading to frustration when the car just doesn't make the turn. This is in stark contrast to its spiritual predecessor, in which the vehicles felt almost weightless. Once you come to terms with Grip's handling, though, it's not bad at all - although classic arcade-style drifting isn't really an option thanks to the understeery model, there's plenty of room for skill in taking optimal lines. The game's big gimmick, the ability to drive on walls and ceilings, works a treat, with transitions being perfectly smooth and tracks making creative use of it. The 'launch' ability allows cars to jump quite a height, and opens up even more possibilities for shenanigans - though I feel it runs the risk of being too much of an extraneous gimmick. Although the vast majority of the time the game behaves very well, there is an unfortunate and long-standing bug which can cause cars to suddenly stop or bounce violently for seemingly no reason. Hopefully this gets squashed, as it is common enough to be frustrating.

The 'combat' part of the combat racer moniker comes with the wide - and still widening - array of powerups at racers' disposal. Appearing as green holograms at predetermined points on the track, pickups will grant one of many weapons and tools for either making someone else's life miserable or making your own more comfortable. Missile hits will blast cars clean off the track, while the 'Ram Raider' generates a repulsive field around your car, pushing adversaries away. The chaos that can ensue when a pack of cars is vying for position is remarkable. There is some limited interplay between powerups - the 'Raptor' machinegun can be used to destroy mines while a barrier shield can protect racers from attacks from behind. Planned for the future is destructible scenery, with the first steps towards that goal being already present on one of the tracks.

Track variety is already quite good, with ten ingame spread across the four environments. There are a couple of arenas to support the deathmatch game mode and a large number of 'carkour' maps that rigorously test your control of the cars. As stated earlier, good use is made of the cars' ability to drive on any surface, especially in tracks created later in development.

There are currently eight cars available across three manufacturers, each with their own visual style and performance specialties. The 'Terra' manufacturer has a bulky, armoured appearance and its cars tend to be good all-rounders. 'Cygon' looks very futuristic and features very polarised cars - they harbour the slowest and most controllable car in the game alongside the fastest and least controllable. 'Vintek' take cues from classic cars, the old rollcage games and a bit of scrapyard chic with surprisingly good agility. Cars are categorised into three groups - the agile, quick-off-the-mark 'speedsters', the balanced 'all rounders' and the fast, tough but unwieldy 'tanks'. Car balance is currently fairly good, with certain cars being favoured over others depending on the track but few situations where a choice would be completely incapable of winning.

[h1]Multiplayer?[/h1]

Splitscreen functionality has been present for a long time and works well, but requires two controllers to work. It will not work with just a keyboard, or a keyboard and a controller at present. Online multiplayer was added recently and is very fun if you can find a race, but has been plagued with crashes, bugs and disconnects. The most recent patch addressed this to a large degree but multiplayer is still very unreliable by most accounts. Numbers online are generally very low, and it's probably best to try and organise races via the game's Discord channel which has a fair few active users.


[h1]Closing thoughts[/h1]

GRIP is already very, very playable. Despite being in early access with all the rough edges and issues that entails it's presented very professionally with active and receptive developers who have a lot of dedication for the game. Although there are still a lot of technical issues - some severe - in many parts of the game (most cripplingly, multiplayer) I am confident that they will be solved in the future. As it is now, racing in singleplayer works perfectly fine and multiplayer is very good fun - if it behaves itself. Though I will recommend the game, be warned that there are many frustrating issues still to be fixed that might not go away for some time.

34892265.review: At first, I was a little hesitant, because I'm sure we all know how a lot of  revamps turn out these days, but I was far from disappointed with GRIP. So far, this is turning out to be exactly like the older Rollcage games. Having played both Rollcage and Rollcage Stage II, GRIP is almost like the late threquel to the series. Yes, it's still a work in progress, and seeing other reviews, lots of people apparently fail to realize that, but it IS getting better. Another thing people complain about is the steering. Well, if you played the above mentioned rollcage games, you'd soon find out that the steering was never easy to begin with, but you gotta practice. There's this wonderful thing called drifting, and it's highly involved in the rollcage series, a lot more so in this one. The old ones, well, of course physics aren't gonna be as good. That's 90's tech right there, but you'd soon find out, especially with the faster vehicles, that you have to drift quite often. All of that aside, I give this game a 5/5, and I'm very much looking forward to what the developer has in store next.

Pour ma part j'aime beaucoup la musique également (adaptée au genre)

Il y a bien sûr quelques points à corriger (le jeu est en cours de développement à l'heure où j'écris donc on peut espérer que cela sera réglé prochainement) notamment :
- les missiles (on ne comprend pas pourquoi on se prend nos missiles dans la figure de façon quasi systématique)
- manque de précision du freinage et lorsque la voiture "vole" j'aurais espéré qu'on puisse réaliser quelques figures ou viser plus précisément l'atterrissage
- le choix des véhicules est trop limité à mon goût (peu de différences de caractéristiques)

Mais ce jeu est très prometteur ! On croise les doigts pour la poursuite du développement :)

34467907.review:
You played "Rollcage"? Then you know what awaits you in this game!

This game brings up the greatest memorys of my childhood, theres been so many excellent  10/10 games and this is one of these.
The nostalgia is back in that meaning, just upgraded and made for 2017.

GRIP is an arcade racing game, more or less a bit scifi setting oriented with cars driving at insane speeds and holding the "GRIP" on whatever surface, that means you can drive headover on the rooftops if you like to or drive on the side of a wall.
While yo do that there are also pickups on the grounds that give you specific effects such as even more speed, a minigun ect. ect. and there are some platforms that provide an extra boost in speed aswell.

As of the current looks this game truly goes into the footsteps of its ancestor "Rollcage" and it has done everything correct so far to bring up the exact same feeling of that game.
One thing that has to be said tho, even if it sounds brilliant there currently still is a bit of content lack - but to keep further growing such a game support is also recommended id say.

And as there is a huge lack of proper games from previous times, i can just say, support this project please.
Years back there has been so many amazing games, fresh ideas and so on - what do we usually get nowadays? Right, a copy of a bad game and another copy of that.

Alot of games havent found their ways into this year and its nice to see some projects like GRIP  picking up very good concepts and bring them into this time.


Some things are missing, small stuff but it gave the previous games that little touch:

- a bit of destruction and firing some rockets on buildings to drop them and maybe give an enemy behind you a bit of a harder time (this was sth good for the 1st place player)
- some pickups miss
- and not so sure but i think some vehicles do still miss in the game.

34251607.review:
(v1.2.4)

Fast paced, extreme intense, overload of fun.

One of the best games I know. It has everything, a good game needs, though it's still WIP.

I can't wait for the initial release!

Pros:
- Very fluently gameplay, even with highest graphical settings.
- Controlls with pad are very intuitive.
- Continued development with very high regardence for community-wishes.
- Graphics are absolute exelent.
- Very good sense of speed.
- Very athmospheric tracks, which differ much from each other.
- Nice vehicle selection, each one with his own pros and cons.
- You can costumize your vehicles to your liking.
- Vehicles are feeling very lively. You have to be VERY precise with your controlls.
- No gamebreaking bugs.
- Nice soundtrack, but also customizable to your own liking. (!)
- Very different gamemodes, each of them with it's own gameplay and loads of fun.
- Very nice price, the fun you get out of it is absolutely worth it!
- Deathmatch is a burner.
- Acrophobic FTW!

Cons: (Which are mostly caused by its WIP-status)
- Experiencesystem seems to have no influence to this point.
- A few bugs on some tracks, which can be a little bit annoying. But nothing gamebreaking.
- Carselection could be a bit more intuitive. You have to select your car in the mainmenu > garage before go to a race.
- Tutorial isn't really helpful. How to use jumps and how to drift, you have to find out by yourself.
- Physics can be annoying also, when every single bump can launch your vehicle to Narnia with no controll at all.
- Even the smallest touch with an opponent sends you spinning round and around.

34113321.review:
Le 09/08/2017
Une suite logique pour les habitués des jeux types "rallcage", un jeu de course original et inhabituel à découvrir pour les autres.
Adapté pour jouer seul, en famille, en réseau local, et en ligne.
Le jeu est encore en développement, le contenu actuel est plutôt léger mais les mises à jours se font petit à petit.
Quelques bug réguliers encore (mais c'est normal pour un jeu en dev, et ne gênent pas trop l'expérence de jeu).
On est surpris par la grandeur des circuits.
Le niveau difficile l'est vraiment.
Beaucoups d'options présentes et prévues pour le multiplayer, assurant une bonne expérience.
(Mais quelques problèmes dans la configurations des touches pour jouer à plusieurs sur le même ordinateur)
Pas encore de "campagnes solo" mais comme tout les circuits ne sont pas encore ajoutés...

La voiture étant plus "lourde", on vole un peu moins dans le décors que dans rallcage mais les arrêts complets peuvent s'averer fatales sur une course.
Ce jeu nous change un peu des zones habituelles de conforts de gamer classique, le renouveau est sympa.

C'est bon jeu que je conseille si vous aimez le genre. Le rapport Contenu / prix est je trouve un peu limite pour l'instant, mais il y a encore le temps pour beaucoup d'ajouts. Donc avant d'acheter, attendez ou soyez sûr d'y passer le temps pour rentabiliser.
 Merci aux développeurs. =)

I really like what this game does, even with the "fast" effects turned off (motion blur and fov expansion off) the sensation of speed is amazing.
And when a track says it's "hard", it's hard, I tried an elimination race on a hard track for a half hour and at most I finished in 7th. The level design is really good with tracks making good use of the game's gimmmicks without using it too much and making the track design confusing, and it blends really well with art style full of alien planets and industrial buildings with nice and varied use of colour, floating roads, rocky tunnels there's a lot of eye candy.

It's fun, it's challenging and track memorization is the route to victory but with 9 other cars on the track armed with guns and rockets on the track it's not a guarantee.

33222658.review:
Une petite perle ! 

GRIP est un jeu de voiture nerveux, trés nerveux ! Mais aussi trés rapide ! 
Ce jeu est une petite perle peut connu malheureusement...

Points Positifs : 
-Nostalgie des jeux de type JackX sur PS2 ! 
-Magniabilité au TOP ! 
-Sensation de vitesse plus que présente ! 
-Modes de jeux varié et interressant 
-Véhicule juste hors du commun 
-Bande son 
-Les maps juste sublime !
-Beau
-Fluide et peut gourmant ! 
-Enfin BEAUCOUP de POSITIF SUR CE JEU ! 

Malgrés tout ces points positifs il y a quelque Bémol, cependant restons indulgent c'est un early accéss donc la plus part sont justifié 

Points Négatifs (Pour le moment c'est a dire le 04/07/2017) : 
-Le jeu a un potentiel OUFF, cependant il n'est pas assez exploiter...
-Il manque franchement un workshop avec des maps communautaires comme trackmania car il a tout le potentiel pour avec nottament les maps de parkour et de time attack (un peut a la trackmania), mais aussi des circuits de course communautaires pour déliré entre pote sur un serv ! 
-Une IA qui meme en hard est pas assez méchante (Patch?)
-Manque de diversité des maps (A prendre avec des pincettes car il y a quelques maps (une 15aines) et le jeu est en develloppement donc ils vont surement en rajouter)
-ON VEUT PLUS DE VEHICULES CAR ILS SONT JUSTE ENORME ! Et si possible avec des caractéristiques propre a chaque véhicule :D 
-Dommage mais il manque une campagne solo.... Elle sera le bien venue 

Conclusion: 
Ce jeu est just une petite perle, malheureusement peut connus avec des serveurs multijoueurs vide (c'est vraiement dommage donc il faut faire de la pub car il mérite le détoure), laissons au devs le temps de continuer dans ce qu'ils font car le jeu est trés bien lancé !!!! Pour le moment, le peut que le jeu a à nous offrire il LE FAIT BIEN ! Le jeu coute 16€ et sans déconné même a 20€ j'aurais doncé dessus  ! 
J'éspere que les devs écoutent la commu et mettent rapidement en place un workshop avec des maps commu pour augmenté le nombres de map ect... 

18/20

33109909.review: I gave it as much a chance as I could, but eventually I get frustrated at the issues this game currently has. The vehicles are too light and will easily fly into the air with every bump, they handle pretty poorly and the camera can have trouble keeping up with all the ground to wall to ceiling driving. Most items work fairly well but the missiles 9/10 times will immediately plow into the ground, despite being locked on to an opponent, causing you to lose control which once again is really easy to do in this game as there isn't much vehicle control.There is "air control" but it's very limited and you can only adjust the sideways roll of the car, you can't adjust the forward and back flips which are  just as if not more important. It does run well on my PC, has nice graphics and music, but unless you can put up with constantly being turned around and flung off the track I can't recommend at this current point in time.

32908598.review:
Key point:
Fast, exciting, high velocity and intense combat racing action!
Lovely game, Give it a try! I love it and I think many other people into arcade racing games with a hint of combat would love it too. 

Opinion piece:

The two games that this game is a spiritual successor to... I loved them as a kid and I loved the idea of Going Fast. I am impressed by Grip, And how the development... its Going Fast. It has the style and velocity of RC1 & RCSII, But as of the writing of the review, I'm very disappointed with the map design. They all seem to want to hinder the idea of “Going fast”. So many obstacles, and blind pit falls. I believe some maps(or sections of maps) should be more streamline. Even the bot racers have issues with navigating some of these maps and they're smarter than we are, assuming they're Ai designed specifically to navigate the maps. Hard mode = Drive off a cliff while trying to bust a switch blade sharp turn at 300mph. And some weapons are just over powered. Good thing its just early access. A lot can change, And I can't wait to see the final product. It would be a dream come true.

As of now, still many things must be worked out such as:

Wonky checkpoints if you have to reset
fine tuning control of the car (still seems like some of the physics are slightly off, not sure)

Multiplayer is a little scare at the momment, if you have Discord. I would reommend going to the games official site and looking for a link to the games discord. There users have been organizing multiplayer games and having a blast. Its been truly awesome to see something like this pop up.

I really wish I could have known about this sooner to support it!

32602982.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
I have been following this game since since the day it was announced.. What a story man.

It all started when Robert Baker arrived in the Rollcage Steam Group, a group of Rollcage fans - the game GRIP inspires itself from - created just for the sake of having some MP games on it. Rob arrived here, and [b]more than 15 years after Rollcage's release[/b], when he saw we were so excited about the game, he agreed to patch the game [b]just for us[/b] so that we could have our multiplayer games. On his free time. This dude is amazing.
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/rollcage/discussions/3/35220315778034627/

Then he met Chris, another Rollcage fan with a lot of experience in UE4, and they decided to start what is now what we (Rollcage fans) thought impossible a couple of years ago - a Rollcage spiritual sequel! They both abandonned their respective jobs, to dedicate themselves to this gem.
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/rollcage#announcements/detail/209761440203015771

On their journey, they faced (and are still facing) a lot of difficulties. They tried a Kickstarter which failed - but nevertheless, they kept going. Despite being outnumbered in regards to the [b]huge[/b] task that represents developing a proper racer, they kept pushing. They are the most determined devs I have known so far, they want to finish this game no matter what it entails.
http://www.gripvideogame.com/

Not only are they working hard - but they're also listening a lot to their community. They encouraged us to give them ideas - and actually, a non negligible amount of features now present in GRIP are the result of propositions and discussions in the main forum. Even when the feedback isn't positive, they're always reading it, and trying to understand what is wrong.

What you're about to experience (if you decide to buy GRIP), is not only a fan game a-la "I want to make a modern version of Rollcage", it's a game where the community played a big role in helping shaping the game.

It's also the result of 2 years of working very hard, the size of the team never bigger than 3-4.

It's not perfect, and there's still a lot of features and rebalancing that need to be done before it becomes a great game. But the devs are aware of it - it's not like some of the games where they say "yeah yeah" and then they do as if they didn't read. They actually acknowledge the defaults of the game in the case of GRIP, and imo it's a great strength that every developer out there should have.

Now that I've given a little bit of context, here is the part more relevant to the actual game content/gameplay.

[h1]What is GRIP ?[/h1]

GRIP is combat racer, which is meant to be intense and very dynamic. Think of Mario Kart, but with actual physics and weapons that actually explode. What puts GRIP apart from the other combat racers, is the craziness of the physics. The vehicles can be driven upside down (and now since a recent update you can even make your vehicle jump), which allows to do some crazy manoeuvers
http://i.imgur.com/I2IoorK.gifv

The tracks can range between "very open with a lot of different paths" to "single road with lots of crazy loops a-la Trackmania". Their design is not perfect, but it shows some huge potential when it comes down to the variety of the tracks and the different environments.

As for the speed, it's supposed to feel very fast. Maybe not as fast as Redout, but fast enough to give you chills. If you can keep up the pace ;)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VtkvfAwY6jE
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HHWfA_LqLxU

The weapons could use more work right now, but their goal is to either blow a vehicle, or just push him out of the way, making his vehicle uncontrollable, etc.. With the "Destruction" option enabled, your vehicle can even blow off if it has taken too much damage. Just like Megarace, but in better :-)
https://youtu.be/DrWRpB1inqI?t=1m17s

GRIP is the kind of game where you can become first quite unexpectedly if you time right your weapons, and if you also have the right opportunities. It's a combat racer, meaning predicting weapons is just as important as racing in itself. This is what made Rollcage so unique, and it's one of the greatest strength of GRIP.

However, GRIP is not perfect, and it does have a few points that prevent it (so far) from becoming a great game:
[list]
[*]Tracks have a bit too much of a "press accelerate and go straight" feeling - some of them would need some additional elements to break that feeling
[*]Weapons also need some rework - some of them are hard to counter, while some others feel not that powerful
[*]GRIP is still not very beginner friendly - racing in GRIP is very special and unlike the other racers out there. It's not as hard as BallisticNG (i mean no offense, I actually love BNG :-) ), but it does require you to be focused while racing
[/list]

But the developers are more than aware of the issues, and step by step we're watching GRIP becoming the game we were waiting for.

An example of something they strived a lot to get working correctly: the steering physics within UE4, the collisions, the traction of the vehicles on the road.. Just racing in general. The first iterations of the game were quite not that right in terms of handling. The devs went as far as [b]modifying the actual UE4 code[/b] to bend it to what they wanted the handling to be. A bunch of crazy people, i'm telling you. But thanks to their dedication, now the handling really feels great, and that's one step closer to what we (the fans) are expecting GRIP to be :-)

If you want to support the developers, and get at least a couple of hours of fun, buy it. You won't regret it.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=v0xBWUbtZbY

32225826.review:
Do I recommend this game? Yes and no. 

- No, mostly due to the car handling that ironically doesn't feel GRIP-py enough. Maybe it's not a fair comparison, but in an arcade racing game like NFS you feel much more in control and at the same time you still drive a highly responsive car. In GRIP it's very easy to totally lose control.
- No, because the physics definitely feel flimsy and unpredictable at times, adding to the frustration. Little bumps can cause your car to unpredictably jump or spin around.

+ Yes, because of the (re)fresh take on the genre. I miss games like Rollcage Stage and and ReVolt, and I think many people do so too.
+ Yes, because of the good graphics (cars look great, environments - not so much)
+ Yes, because of the awesome DNB soundtrack and juicy sound design
+ Yes, because of the numerous game modes that should end up in the final game (there are  just a few atm)

GRIP has a lot of potential to reach great heights, maybe those of Rocket League, but still needs a lot of blood and sweat invested by the developers :)
Note that as of the moment of writing this review there aren't many active players so you will need a buddy if you want to play in multiplayer.

32216693.review:
Wer sich noch an die Ära der PS1 High-Speed Rennspiele erinnert der kennt vor allem einen Namen: "Psygnosis". Damals schon fast ein Synonym für technische Brillianz und Geschwindigkeit mit Titeln wie WipeOut und dem Magenumdrehenden Ungetüm das sich Rollcage nannte. Dieser Titel ist die Grundlage für Grip und das spürt man sofort genauso wie die Beteiligung ehemaliger Entwickler des Originals. Obwohl sich der Titel noch im EA befindet, ist es einer der wenigen, die gefühlt regelmässig mit schönen Updates versorgt werden und seit seiner Veröffentlichung große Fortschritte gemacht hat.

Basierend auf UE4 Grafiktechnologie sieht das Spiel entsprechend gut aus und das Geschwindigkeitsgefühl ist herausragend, auch ist die Fahrphysik bis auf wenige Ausnahmen bereits toll gelungen. Sehr positiv finde ich das die Programmierer dem Spiel einen lokalen Splitscreen Modus spendiert haben und das vor kurzem auch der Online Multiplayer Part eingefügt wurde. Daher empfehle ich den Titel bereits jetzt jedem Rennspiel-Nostalgiker und bitte darum dieses fähige Team mit dem Kauf des Spiels zu unterstützen.

vorl. Fazit: 8.1/10

32196813.review:
Early Access review as it stands!

Graphics: So the graphics are actually pretty decent for an indie dev team.  They offer some very very decent graphical aspects of the game and some overal a nice detailing on the cars, tracks, weapons, explosions and runs smooth! - There are some nice detailing like EMP strikes shaking the map and things falling down.

Audio: The audio of the game is very nice! The music is constant and you can turn it off if wanted, the engines do sound different but the weapons, guns, explosions etc offer some nice sound effects into the game when racing through the maps with chaos behind you.

Controls: The controls I found super easy to use because I was using an Xbox one controller in my PC.  Not a single problem with the game in this aspect and perfectly fine to use and play with keyboard if need be!

Gameplay and everything else: The game is basically a revisit off the old 1999 Rollcage game, which at the time was amazing and top fun... It was my childhood game I would say!

Problem I found was the lack off maps.  There is a fairly decent amount of modes and content, it is just the lack of maps that makes it slightly sad, but the gameplay style, fun, multiplayer etc makes the game an awful lot of fun to be had!

The game is fast paced and should be played with friends for maximum enjoyment and the game is still in early access as I write this review, so please bare that in mind!

If you are racing, then it is simple objective to win and by any means, so blowing them up and setting mines etc.. Move as fast as possible and do not stop with the insane speeds at hand.  You can also traverse the walls and roofs to not stop and there are things in the way to slow you down!

There are nothing to unlock from what I can tell so you do not need to grind to get unlocks.. Which is good! You can just in and play!

You can change a various amount of vehicles and rims, colours and so on to make your ideal vehicle..

Would I recommend this game? Yes! Without a doubt one of the funnest silliest racing games out there.  It does not try to be serious, hard or anything it is not.  It is a fun fast, mayhem shooting racing game to just be had and enjoyed.

31692710.review:
[b]Overview of pros and cons:[/b]

+ Classic handling and feel of Rollcage
+ Plenty of thrilling speed
+ Mostly well-designed circuits boasting gorgeous visuals

- Erratic physics can unfairly ruin your race
- Dull soundtrack


[b]Full review:[/b]

As much as I want to adore this game, I very nearly chose to rate it down on account of certain shortcomings which, at least for the time being during this stage of early access, prevent me from being able to commend this title as a truly refined and fulfilling arcade racer experience. Thankfully though, there's still some good fun to be had by virtue of the aspects of the game that shine.

First and foremost on the positives; anybody who loved Rollcage back in the day will naturally wonder whether Grip succeeds in paying homage to the aforementioned game that inspired its design, and for the most part I reckon it does. The circuits flow well and are great fun to blast round at blistering speeds, often prompting the player to defy gravity by tearing along walls and ceilings, as is iconic of the original Rollcage. By that same token, the cars handle with the same general feel as in the original game, abiding by just the right amount of traction and inertia relative to the car you've chosen and the type of terrain of the circuit being driven. An especially excellent feature is being given the option to promptly respawn your car if you get into a pickle trying to regain composure following a collision or sustained attack, however this doesn't always work perfectly, sometimes spawning you too far behind or ahead of where you just were, though this is something that may be resolved with future updates.

The visuals are not only gorgeously detailed but wonderfully optimized as well. Running this game on my GTX 970 at maximum quality, this is one of the best looking arcade racers I've ever played, yet not once have I encountered a noticeable drop below 60 frames per second. If I had to nitpick, I would only say that the general atmosphere and visual vibe of Grip are somehow more sterile and not quite as “groovy” as that of Rollcage, but on the whole, the different circuits and worlds are nonetheless very pretty, as well as the selection of cars.

Now onto the negatives. The soundtrack, while suitably fast paced, is utterly dull and forgettable, certainly in comparison to the soundtrack of Rollcage; you might as well just find the latter on YouTube and have that playing instead while you race!

And going back to the subject of handling; while Grip does indeed honor the general feel of Rollcage, the unfortunate side effect of this is that your car will sometimes lose control in a seemingly spontaneous manner, rather than as a consequence of your own error. For instance, I'll sometimes be driving along my usual racing line whilst traversing a bump in the track, then all of a sudden my car will act upon its own will and just decide to spin out or flip into the air, only to land back down facing the wrong way and thus ruining my momentum, and all by no fault of my own. This is why you can't afford to take this game too seriously or competitively, because no matter how skilled you may be, every player is ultimately subject to the precarious nature of the game's physics, meaning that you always need some luck on your side in order to maintain control of your car at high speeds, even when you're not being attacked by mines or missiles. Moreover, your car can sometimes be rather slow to initially pick up speed after grinding to a halt, making undeserved spinouts and such all the more tedious.

This characteristic of the game may be a forgivable flaw for some players, perhaps even an oddly desirable quality for others, but for me it undermines the general appeal of competing for superior lap times in time trial mode. To elaborate on that, I feel that an impressively quick lap time should always be the product of almost nothing but skill, judgment and experience, but in the case of Grip, luck plays too large a part in this regard. For instance, it's dissatisfying when another player of the same level of skill manages to set a lap time that's really tough to beat just because they had one lucky attempt whereby their car behaved in a consistently stable manner throughout the lap, despite their judgment having been no better in terms of racing line. I'm hoping that this inconsistency in the game's physics will at least be mitigated as updates continue to be made, though I'm not counting on it.

Lastly, the variety of weapons/pickups is, at least currently, kind of meager. I wouldn't mind seeing at least two more types of pickups introduced, to help prevent skirmishes from growing stale.

On the whole, as long as you don't play with an especially competitive frame of mind, lovers of Rollcage in particular will find that there's a good bit of fun to be had here.

As the spiritual successor of the rollcage series this Title is great, it has the multipath tracks, it has the driving on the ceiling and the fast paced action of the rollcage series, It also has the ever so frustrating but equally as awesome feeling when you get hit or hit the race leader on the last straight with a homing missle. 

But in its own right it's also a success, the tracks feel vast and the lap path choices are plentiful and visually you don't feel like your looking at any sort of placeholder artwork while racing around the tracks.

The only downside for me thus far, is the steering feels very light beyond slow speeds and where you feel like you should be drifting/sliding in offroad surroundings you just don't and the In-air controls are quite obvious to begin with and take a lot of playing around with to get any sort of use out of.

I'm eager to see where this title goes as it comes up to a final release

31588498.review:
Pros~

Devs are taking an active interest in updating the game.

Devs are taking an active interest in the player's mental status in regards to Acrophobia (fear of heights).

Graphics are smooth, and fun to look at. 

Adjustable graphics.

Adjustable FPS range.

Config file can be tweaked for potato computers (not recommended).

Able to use an XBOX or Steam controller with this game.

Local Split-screen/LAN/Nearby Players/Global Queue

Death Race style gameplay.

Vehicular weaponry. 

Fun, upbeat techno keeps the races going to pulse pounding tunes.

Able to add bots to online/LAN games.

Able to set the number of laps for online/LAN games. 

Able to queue for map specific options.

Good for people with short attention spans.

Active online player base.




Cons~

Races seem to look like they start at a snails pace, as if the world is somehow slower. However, as you take off, the FPS adjusts accordingly to your general position, and relative speed. It just screws with me a bit, even though it's not actual lag.

After race camera: I cannot choose which angle the camera is in, and it rapidly switches between the available camera positions. This is a serious draw back, since most of what I'm seeing is happening too quickly. Allowing the player to choose which camera angle to have, would be vastly superior to auto-switching angles.

GRIP is a hyper-fast deathmatch racing game made in the vein of 90s classics Wipeout and Rollcage. Its adrenaline-pumped gameplay is reinforced by spectacular visuals and booming sounds. GRIP also has a very short learning curve. It only takes one or two races to get a good [i]grip[/i] of the controls.

While GRIP might not offer revolutionary new mechanics, it takes a proven formula and redelivers it in a fresh, modern package. GRIP is fast, furious, and most of all – fun.

My only [i]gripe[/i] worth mentioning is how the local splitscreen multiplayer supports only two players and how this severely limits playing the game in groups. This can change, however, as the game is still early access (at the time of this review).

31360289.review:
So I've just logged 24 hours in early access.

Long story short, I've never had this much raw fun in a racing game since Burnout 3 back in 2004, and it's only getting better with each update. Kudos to Caged Element for reviving Rollcage in spectacular fashion.

So yes, yes you should buy this game. However, I feel as if there's some expectations about Grip worth addressing after reading through some other reviews.

Remember that Grip is a [b] battle racer, [/b] and gearing up to be a hardcore one at that. There's going to be collisions, explosions, bumps, jumps, missiles, mines and a whole wealth of other upsets lap after lap that can make this game an intense ride at the best of times, and you'll need to embrace this before you can really begin to enjoy this game for what it is: a battle racer.

Yes, the bleeping warnings of an incoming payload may trigger PTSD as you pray in vain for a shield pick-up or sharp evasive manoeuvre, but one missle impact and a handbrake turn later, the real fun is had chasing back up the pack with two fresh machine guns and one lap left to run - even more so online.

And should worst come to worst, if you find yourself gracefully flipping 60ft up in the air with thrusters in the wrong direction, just remember that there's a reset button. Map that baby to something memorable and use it well.

[b] Grip's races can be hard to win, and that's exactly the way it should be for a game of this calibre. [/b]

It should go without saying, but if you want a conventional racing experience without (sometimes literal) bumps in the road, then this isn't the game you're looking for.

All in all, for an early access game Grip so far is phenomenal. Sure enough, there's plenty more to be added yet with regards to content, and car physics are still being tweaked to perfection, but as it stands?

Hot damn.

31306066.review:
GRIP is one of the best feeling modern arcade-style racing games. Obviously arcade racers are rare these days, but GRIP is the best of the indie arcade racing lot.

The tracks are open enough to incentivize a little exploration to find shortcuts yet not so open to allow you to get lost while racing and rely on the minimap. The weapons pack an immediate race-changing punch, unlike those in Formula Fusion or Redout which just sap away at your strength leading to a complete loss.

The AI is fun to play against. I didn't notice any rubber banding, but the AI is able to hang in there and use weapons in a way that feels very natural.

The visuals, and perhaps even moreso the visual style, are excellent. I think these are some of the best looking vehicles and tracks in a modern arcade racer. This game has style for days.

31240720.review:
[b]Note:[/b] I am completely aware that this game is an early access title, therefore the review will be built a little differently. But I will not hold back on any criticism that I might have. I will update this review as new updates arrive (Review was last updated on the [b]26th of October, 2017[/b])

GRIP is a spiritual successor to Rollcage/Rollcage 2, with polished graphics and physics.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]» Driving physics[/b]
The driving physics are a serious step up compared to the Rollcage-titles. However, I think the vehicles could use a little more grip on dirt-services, and a little less on asphalt. Perhaps a kind of drift-system would also be nice, because steering as of now kind of feels a little strange.

[b]» Tracks[/b]
The race tracks all have a good amount of curves and straights, however, compared to the Rollcage titles, they are way less unique and varied. Most tracks look quite barren without much going on, although the new maps definitely look promising! A track editor would be pretty interesting, but maybe that's too much to ask.

Speaking of destruction: As of now, the game is really missing out on that. The most destruction I ever saw were some knocked around barrels, that's pretty much it.

Furthermore, the mirrored mode is very appreciated, you don't see that in many newer titles.

[b]» Vehicles[/b]
There are a bunch of vehicles to choose from with different stats. They are all modifyable with different colors, wheels and tyres. All vehicles look pretty unique; a very good step up from the Rollcage series.

[h1]Misc[/h1]
[b]» Splitscreen[/b]
[b]THIS GAME HAS A SPLITSCREEN MODE.[/b] More games need this.

[b]» Soundtrack[/b]
The soundtrack is not really of my taste, personally. I preferred the style of the Rollcage games with great Jungle/DnB tracks. It's just too wobbly, it's missing that raw-ness and punch. But that's just me, everyone's taste in music is different.

[b]» Graphics[/b]
The graphics look very beautiful. Bloom effects, motion-blur, etc. look just right. Although the performance is a little lacking on higher resolutions/settings and the framerate likes to drop a little sometimes (Playing this at 4k on a 980ti felt kinda sluggish).

[b]» Settings[/b]
The game has tons of settings. Shadows, object quality, post-processing, etc, etc. There also is a FOV setting, which is really appreciated. The only thing that is missing is a master-volume slider, that would be great.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
This game is not a bad racer at all. It feels fast, and it's difficult. While the lack of varied maps is kind of bugging me (although that seems to be fixed soon), I'd say it has serious potential.

31240309.review:
First of all, let me say this... I'm very sceptical if it's about Early Access games. Those "games" often tend to be scams just to rip You off. However, that's not the case for GRIP. This game, for me, is a proof that there are studios out there that genuinely care about their projects and their fanbase. Caged Element are the good guys. Why You ask? I had this game on my radar for a long time, since I saw the first trailer, and the devs are constantly adding new stuff to the game, fixing bugs and tweaking the mechanics etc. This game is evolving, it keeps getting better and better. It traveled a long way since it's first versions.

I won't be comparing this game to it's predecessor Rollcage. I'll focus entirely on my feelings while playing, without any nostalgia involved. Also keep in mind GRIP is constantly growing so my "review" can become out of date. I will update it i there will be a need for it.

So... GRIP is an amazing combat racer, with exciting gameplay and amazing audio-visuals. It's fast, it's aggresive, sense of speed on highest engine power is face-melting, and to top it off, its Drum & Bass soundtrack is a cherry on the cake, it will make Your blood boil if that's the type of music You dig. And even if You don't, there is always the option to throw Your own music to the playlist but to be honest I didn't test this feature well enough because I thought it's unnecessary, for me, the original soundtrack is perfect.

Gameplay itself feels demanding at first. Getting used to the vehicles take a little bit of time since it's not the type of racer where You can just hold the accelerate button to win, You must actually tame Your vehicle to have a chance of winning, they are designed in a way to allow driving on the walls and ceiling and it takes some practice and track knowledge. Every vehicle has different statistics, and even though the differences are subtle, they have a big impact on Your driving, You have to match the car to Your driving preference. For example, there is Cygon Ictus that is very agile but it can only take a few rockets on its face to blow up. On the other hand there is Vintek Juggernaut that is a typical tank and it can take much more hits but its handling is worse. And there are some cars in the middle also. Currenly there are more middle weight and tanks class in the game and only one speedster but it's going to change with the upcoming update.

Now, the tracks themselves. They are classified in three categories, easy, normal and hard, and some of them are insanely hard. There are a total amount of 7 tracks right now and some of them comes with their reversed versions. Some of them are taking place on the ground and some of them are taking place high in the sky in a form of roads suspended in the air, and those are among the hardest. Environments are interesting, good looking, pleasant for the eyes. Even though there are not much tracks at the moment, there are options to stop You from being bored. For example, You can mirror every track so it can have a slightly different feel, so if You choose to race on a reversed and mirrored, it feels like You're racing on a completely different track. You can change vehicle destruction, number of contestants, number of loops and turn on/off the upgrades appearing on the road.

Is there only racing mode? No. There is Classic Racing where only Your position matters. There is a Ultimate Racing where You gather points by being first and by using Your weaponry on the opponents. There is the Eliminator where every last car explodes every 30 seconds and it goes until one car survives (it's hard as hell btw) and there is my favourite mode which is Time Attack where You race alone infinitely just to improve Your track time. I tend to spend most time on Ultimate and Time Attack. There are also three arenas where there is no racing involved at all. You just have to kill Your opponents with rockets and mines. That mode took me by surprise, I didn't think I would like it, even though it's simple it is still a fun mode.

...but is there something wrong about GRIP? It's pretty impossible to create flawless game and GRIP is no exception. There are occasional issues with collision boxes where You can bounce unexpectedly or get stuck. It happens more often at breakneck speeds but even then it's rare. Also, You have to be careful where and when You shoot Your rockets because if used in the wrong place and time the rocket can slam back at You immediately after deploying. As far as I know it's the issue the devs are currently fixing.

There is also another mode in which I've put the most hope but it turned out to be the most boring one by far. I'm speaking about the Playground mode. It was created due to people demand (I'm not going to hide, I was one of those people), it resembles the Scramble mode from Rollcage where You test Your driving skills on a very demanding short tracks. For some reason, this mode feels simply uninteresting. It feels like it was added as a bonus, like it's a very unpolished DLC or something. I have two predictions about this mode, either it will be improved last after tweaking the core mechanics of the game... or it will be obsolete and deleted in the future patch. Time will tell.

Well... I wrote an essay didn't I? Long story short... I love this game and I can't wait how it will evolve in recent months, or even years. GRIP can be the best futuristic racer of 2017 if Caged Element will still work on it at their current pace.

31069305.review:
Graphically, Grip is amazing, once you find that seet spot in the settings. By default, the settings had everything sluggish and really almost unplayable... and I have a fairly good system. A few tweaks, including having to reduce the resolution to 720p and killing all graphical enhancements, including the blur effect, she was purring like a kitten. Even at reduced settings, the game still looks sweet, but I can't help but think about what it could look like. Controls are fairly tight once you get the hang of it, but it's one hell of a hard game to handle at times. When you reach top speeds, if you hit one thing wrong, you're sent flying all over the track with little to no chance of recovery. I was in first place and just seconds away from the finish line when I was reduced to 8th. When you loose control, you really loose control. That being said, Grip is one of those games that plays a lot like Wipeout which to me was equally as frustrating, but still balls out fun!

At the time of writing this review, I have only put in close to an hour, but with racing games that's all I need to get a feel for it. It is still in early Access, so hopefully they'll tweak it some more, but in its current state it feels like a finished product.

A well made, beautiful, fun and exhilirating game!! I'm a very happy Kickstarter backer!

Things to keep in mind:

- I tried playing this on an MSI 970 on low settings in 1080P and the game would go from 20FPS to 40FPS contantly, making driving nearly impossible. After getting a 1080 Ti card and setting everything to EPIC with 1440P screen, this game flies!!! And the GPU is only loaded 36% during the entire game session. (TLDR; Get a proper GPU!)

- It's important to note that the "reset" button is important to bind or you will hit your head against the wall every time you go out-of-bounds - which you will, repeatedly!

- The Multiplayer is very fun but needs a bit clearer "status" so you know what to do and how it works, joining an ongoing game can make you wait 20 minutes...

31001580.review:
[EDIT: 9/2017 - Basic race mode no longer includes weapons. A welcome change. Thank you.]

Though GRIP is now more than a year old, I can recall only the vaguest memory of it before its current multiplayer iteration. And that is a great shame, since it’s quite a remarkable game. This week it’s my favorite (non-pinball) game, and that’s even including some wonderful racing/driving games. But it’s not perfect...

(For this review, I consider SINGLE-PLAYER only. At least for now.)

GRIP, as the Store Page indicates, is a futuristic racing game, taking place on other planets with a varied selection of technologically advanced vehicles. What really makes these “cars” stand out….they can’t land wrong! (Other than backwards.) Because of design, whatever side they land on is the bottom, and they can instantly GO!!!...reaching speeds of about 600 MPH (1,000 KPH.) Of course, at those speeds, steering requires some substantial degree of precision, and even a small bump (or impact) can send a car HUNDREDS of feet into the air........!

What makes GRIP special? You don’t have to be a great driver-gamer to have fun, or even to do well. While an experienced driver will certainly have an edge (especially with “newbie buttons” turned off), unlike most racing games, any player should outright WIN some percentage of races. And there’s even a “bail-out” button; holding the “respawn” button will get you back in the race with little time or distance lost, almost no matter the situation you may be in.

GRIP is hard to explain. The vehicles basically “stick” to the track, so players will often find themselves traveling at high speeds……completely upside down. And that's often not obvious until something goes wrong, and gravity instantly takes control.

The GRIP tracks are beautifully designed for functionality, as well as appearance. The Store Page trailers and screenshots say more than my words can begin to express (so I won’t try, except to say that what they add to the game can’t be measured.) Most tracks offer shortcuts that may offer an advantage….. if you dare! I expect to still be discovering new nooks and crannies for quite some time.

The GRIP cars offer features very specific to players’ driving styles. Fortunately, I quickly found a car that suits beginning drivers (such as myself); slower, but with maximum control (and at average speeds of 250 – 300 MPH, good to have.) None of the cars are locked (and in fact, nothing in GRIP is locked at this point.) But none of the cars can be upgraded either. Yes, their color and rims can be changed (yawn), as can the tires. But does a tire change alter performance? Hard to say, and GRIP isn’t talking (that I could find.)

The GRIP game modes are pretty standard. Simple racing (yet with weapons. Strange.....), battle racing, elimination racing and best time with one player only. For beginners, I’d strongly suggest the time trials. Being on the course alone is the best way to learn the tracks. (Although just being thrown unto an unknown track with nine other racers has a certain undeniable, desperate charm as well!) There are also two Deathmatch arenas and something referred to as “Carkour” that one presumes to be a form of car parkour. I have little experience with either.

While GRIP’s best features speak for themselves (and LOUDLY so!), there are some less fortunate aspects that should be noted:

While the tracks available are great, there aren’t very many of them, and almost half of them are simply reversals.

Almost everything about each race is GREAT! But then what? There is no type of progression (at least for single player.) Presumably, much of the reason is that there are so many variables, possibilities and options, it would be difficult to create a standardized system of progression. Yet, it takes much out of the game (in this player’s opinion) to go nowhere. For example, currently in battle races, the final scoreboard has to wait for all racers to complete to finish calculating (even if you're last), which often never happens, no matter how long one waits. But the player soon realizes; So what if there’s no final score posted? It would serve no purpose in GRIP’s current form.

Pickups are basically a “learn as you go” process, as well as studying the controller settings to try to understand how to use them. There’s nothing even remotely like a tutorial, and that would be VERY helpful (at least for beginners.) Which is a weapon? Which is a tool? What do the symbols mean? How do you use them?

GRIP’s battle system is weak. Some weapons have little purpose, are badly utilized by the controller, and come with no explanation. (In fact, the only difference between the regular race and battle race is the final scoring method. This seems inexcusable.) The notification of points scored is almost meaningless. (Who did what, and to whom? Green text? Red text? Which name first…or second?)

Personally, I find techno music lacks the sort of heart-pounding intensity I would choose for such immersive racing, but players have the option to race to their own music as well.

The cameras can behave unpredictably, especially if you happen to get turned around, or are involved in a collision. And more camera choices really need to be considered.

Best scores aren't stored. What's your best time on time trials? Your best Battle race score on a certain track? Once you leave that mode, it's gone forever.

While GRIP has many changes to consider (some of which will be dealbreakers for many gamers), it’s still a fun game with lots of potential at a reasonable price. If these changes are made, this could be a top tier game. Otherwise, it’s still a fun game, just not with the power to keep most players’ attention for an extended period of time. (NOT written as a criticism, simply as an observation of a VERY competitive genre I've spent a respectable amount of time in.)

Thank you.

Along with Redout I consider Grip one of the best futuristic racers available on Steam.

I guess the best way to describe it is this: you drive huge, rocket powered tractors that can be flipped upside down and still drive without issue (wheels are magnetically attached). This means that level design can get pretty crazy. Thankfully, it does.
There's plenty of variety on the tracks, but they are all designed to let you do weird stunts like driving on walls and ceilings all while you shoot everything on sight. 

It also has really good visuals, great performance, split screen support (this is a huge plus for me) and a unique, rough looking visual style. 

It's good! I highly recommend it for fans of the genre.

30980970.review:
Warning: This game is still in development! 

Having that said, this game proves 2 things.

1: Arcade racing is far from dead. 
2: '90s/ '00s gameplay still has a reason for existing today. 

I will explain these points. This game is based on a late PSX arcade racer called Rollcage. It was a futuristic racer like Wipeout and F-zero, with speed and course layout were the primary focus of the game. As with wipeout, Rollcage had weapons, which (if used correctly) could give you an edge or help you get back in the race. But most of all it was the rush of combining the speed, chaos and great music that made the game great.

GRIP doesn't do much different than Rollcage did in it's days. It's still amazingly fast, it's tracks are still build to give you that awesome rollercoaster feeling and the music still completes the experience. But it only adds to that old Rollcage game with everything we like from our games these days, without taking anything away. 

The graphics are great, the tracks look magnificent, with my avagage PC setup the game moves at a steady 60 fps, weapons look awesome and work like a charm the 6 cars (which differ more than enough) sound great with each car another engine sound,. Talking about sound, there is so much quality and detail in that department here. We got the different engine sounds per car, the speed boosts sound powerful, you can hear the drivetrain sqeak at high speeds, missiles and machineguns sound great and the music completes it. 

You can do some basic car customisation by choosing the color of your car's paintwork, changing the rims and their paintjob and change which kind of tires you want on the car (although it doesn't change how the car handles). 

Then there are quite a few tracks and game modus (including a new online multiplayer) added to the game allready, but more will come. Tracks can be rough, which might make your car bump out of bounds, but resetting your car to the track is both easy and looks awesome too. 

The best thing is: the action and fun is so good, that it doesn't matter if you get 1st or last. It brings a smile to your face and before you know it, you are in another race, having the time of you life boosting through upsidedown tunnels, blasting other cars away, dodging obstacles and enjoying the immense sense of speed this game gives you. 

Rollcage is back, better than ever and now for the new generation to enjoy :D

30979145.review: A very fun futuristic arcade racer, lovingly executed.

30971156.review:
Oh my goodness. I don't know what to say! I bought this game, having entirely missed that it's in Early Access, and STILL found myself grinning ear-to-ear and laughing - with no one else around - at how tremendously silly and fun this game is! What a gem! I can't wait for it to be completed. I never played the games it's based on, either, so nostalgia is not a factor, here.

As for the mechanics, the racing is glorious and smooth. If you see a smooth surface, you can drive on it...and ramp off of it, transfer to the ceiling of a tunnel, stay stuck to it somehow, come rocketing our the other end, land upside-down onm a wall, and keep going. The game also clearly tells you when a feature isn't quite ready for primetime: there's a work-in-progress map in the game, multiplayer is present but incomplete, menu navigation is limited to mouse input in parts...and I know everything is working as currently intended because the game is actually upfront with what's being worked on.

On top of that there are options I don't normally expect to see in cheap racing games (or, in fact, *any* arcade racing games). The HUD has a visibility slider, you can adjust the FOV up to basically fisheye levels, you can disable certain crash effects - although honestly the crash effects on the HUD are so mental that I love them, you can toggle slow-mo in a race by hitting Select on the controller, there are several types of game modes with multiple different types of tracks and arenas to accomodate them.

I'm sure there are issues, and I've only played for an hour or so, but I have been enjoying the game so much that I had to close out and give it a hearty recommendation.

30970473.review:
Like the old Rollcage game but with modern graphics with the Unreal Engine 4. It does look really nice and performance is good as well. The content is still a bit lacking but there are more cars and tracks and everything planned for the full release. 

If you want this for multiplayer, then don't be fooled by the low playerbase. You will only be able to race with 10 people at the same time anyway and you can connect to a race which is already in progress, although you need to wait till the next round. So as long there are more than 10 players in multiplayer you won't notice any difference between 10,000 or 100 people playing it, since you will find a lobby with players right away and can't play with more than 10 anyway. Also missing players are replaced by bots to fill up the field if that is the case.

Now I am not sure how many hours I will spend in this game but it is a really fun arcade futuristic racer and is basically a true Rollcare remastered version one could say. Definitely worth spending time on a few multiplayer races every other evening.
