[h1]Not what it was meant to be.[/h1]

I've been here from pretty much when the game was released on Steam in Early Access. At the start, it all was looking promising. Dev team although comprised of just two people, was actually listening to community and doing their best to make this a spiritual successor to the Rollcage games. That however was then...

At the moment of typing this review, I've just finished playing the game after a few months break from it. A break that was caused with me not being happy about the direction the devs were taking the game. Unfortunately the game has exactly the same feel as I last played it... one could argue it means it's worse given how much more development time has passed since then.

So what exactly is the issue? The game is advertised as a spiritual successor of Rollcage, but aside from the cars looking similar... it feels nothing like a Rollcage game. The best way to describe this game would be... a mish mash of games like Rocket League, Mario Kart, Need For Speed and what not. This game lacks identity and you can feel it very quickly. It tries to be everything while at the same time it doesn't really do anything well enough to be anything. Racing gets boring/annoying/frustrating (feeling depends on the track) after just few laps, let alone few races. There's quite literally nothing that makes you want to keep playing the game. And that's probably the biggest crime any game can do.

Here's a more concrete list of everything else that is a problem:
- physics are still broken (after nearly 2 years in development...), you get random bounces here and there, cars take ages to settle down properly after a landing and it doesn't take much to make you crash. One could call the game a "reset simulator" and would be very on point with that description.
- Acceleration is brutally low until you get to 350km/h. There are cars in real life that will beat you to 350km/h... production cars that you "can" buy. This means that the start of each race feels like you're in a slow motion and it only forces the "reset simulator" feel even more. Not what you would expect from AWD jet powered tanks with insane traction and brutally low centre of gravity.
- Developers throw features at the game instead of actually tackling the problems. Namely jumping and nitrous. Jumping with few thousand tons tanks? You'd need a nuclear bomb blast to get those things off the ground, let alone some "poof". Those ain't RC cars that you can grab with your hand... and Nitrous? It only exacerbates the problems, since it barely helps with acceleration when below 350km/h... and there's already a pickup that is supposed to act like a turbo...
- Pace of the game is incredibly slow and chaotic, rather than fast paced and brutal. By that I mean everything takes too much time to do, be that cars acceleration or weapons deployment time or the speed at which they travel and you have little to no control over what happens. In Rollcage you could always do something and everything was very quick, almost instant.
- Menu navigation with gamepad/keyboard is still non-existent. Or should I say it went from working (not great but better than nothing) to nothing and ever since it's been "gamepad and keyboard navigation is coming". Yeah, right -_-


That's pretty much all. The main two issues are essentially the devs and... well... game itself being boring. Rest simply adds insult to the injury.
Now to make this clear, I'm not expecting a Rollcage game with newer graphics. That would be a sequel. I expected a spiritual successor. In other words a game that may work slightly different but still has the same feeling about it. This feels nothing like a Rollcage game. In that sense it's a scam. If you're a Rollcage fan or simply value your money... DO NOT buy/support this game.


[h2]TL;DR;[/h2]
- Devs are no longer listening to the community and are throwing content at the problems instead of solving them.
- Game gets boring after few laps. Doesn't keep you in.
- Physics still broken.
- Slow paced and chaotic gameplay, instead of being fast and brutal.
- Keyboard/Gamepad menu navigation still not implemented.
- This is NOT a spiritual successor to Rollcage.

22742822.review:
Just bought the early access to the game and had fun with it for at least an hour.
Small time to judge but I think first impressions are the ones that weight the most.

Being an hardcore fan of Rollcage I was super stoked to find that someone was making a game in the same racing style, I played Rollacage and Rollcage stage II till nausea, and I still have them both in original boxes, and managed to play them on win 7. Now I am on win 10.

So to the game:
. Graphic is stunning, UT engine is really doing his job at full force here and I played the game at maximum graphic level.

. Music fits perfectly the game pace and puts you in the right mood of futuristic races, I really felt like going back to the good ol wipeout 2097 or Dethkarz (anybody here who played it? that was incredible!)

. Concept is really well done, I loved the different ambientations of the three tracks I could race into. This is very important because a player really need to have in mind the world where the track is located and to have a clear idea of it, I mean "this is snow track, this is jungle track that is desert, etc etc"

. Cars: that's where I would have to point something: I think it would be good to have more differentiation in cars, maybe on the aesthetics but most of all in stats. I was searching for car stats!!! (acceleration, grip, top speed, etc) 
More car identity please!

. I couldn't really understand the difference between the two leagues, except for car being a little more "tanky"

. Playabilty: difficulty is not a problem, but car control it is. I know we are talking about a "scrambled eggs" race type game, but I played Rollcage a lot, in GRIP if you lose control of the car it's a bit more difficult to regain it.

Except for this this is a race game I was hoping to find and I am really glad it's in the making (and it's still in Alpha!)
So if you like the genre and you come from millions of hours of race with rollcage, dethkarz, wipeout like me, keep an eye on GRIP cause it really may be the present day futuristc race game we always wanted. Can't wait to play online!

Played on:

CPU: Intel Sandy Bridge 2550K 3,30Ghz
RAM: 16 gb corsair dominator
GPU: Sapphire Radeon HD 7950 Vapor-X
MOBO: Asus P8Z68 Pro
OS: Windows 10

22590246.review:
Not a bad game (so far) I just finished my first race and am "miledly" impressed. This game still needs work. I'll have a more detailed review once I get used to the game. If you are wondering if you should buy this game now, I would wait till they get the carrier mode up. I purchased this game to support it's development. And I've only played this game once. So far, it's OK.

Update:
Their are 5 modes of solo play and a two player mode. I haven't tried the 2 player mode but their is no online multiplayer mode (yet). Their are 12 cars to choose from, 6 Dominator and 6 Dreadnaught. The Dominators have more speed and less armor, wile the Dreadnaughts have more armor, less speed.

Available game modes:
Races: 
A standered racing mode, choose between two available tracks. Place 1st to win.
Elimination:
If your last, you loose. 
Deathmatch:
Use weapon pick-ups to destroy the other players. (This mode realy could benifit from online multiplayer).
Playground:
Drive around collecting power up icons. A good place to practice handling your car. 
Time Trial:
Beat you own time each lap. (What did you expect)

What needs improving (IMO).

Online Multiplayer in Races, Elimination, and Deathmatch. 
Use Playground as a stunt run and rack up points towards Steam goals.
Hidden cars and tracks.

I hope the developers are reading this. And I hope you, the Steam community, found this review helpfull. If you're looking in to buying this game now, I would only buy it to support it, otherwise, their's not that much to hold you over. For now.

22573960.review:
First of al: I love it and looking forward to the full game!

Combat racing is fun! Its not the easyest game. First few tries I came in 10th or 9th but eventually you learn how the car handles and you are able to lap opponents, even on hard difficulty.
I found it better with engine power set to high as the cars accelerate a lot quicker and therefor easier to recover when facing the wrong way.
a tip: set engine power to max.
Track design looks nice, but sometimes its (especially in the beginning or split screen) its hard to see upcoming obstacles. When you eventually know the track, you know where the are and ok to navigate around.

I also found that the menu is not controller friendly. You really need the D-pad to navigate the menus. With the analog stick of an xbox 360 controller its easy to overshoot that option you want to set.
The AI is is OK. If you master the game its pretty easy to get to the front and stay there. Its also nice that the AI tries to block you when you are driving slightly faster just behind them.

What I would like to see is that the AI accellerates of the starting grid. Now and then they hit the trottle a bit later, seeming they don't pay attention and you eventually need to drive around or into them. When a race starts, everyone should accelerate as fast as the can!

Pros
- AI that tries to block you
- Spit screen rules!
- Grahpics look amaizing
- Mediocre to learn, hard to master
- Speed!
- If you fuck up, it's really your own fault!

Cons
- Recovering with low engine power is slooow
- Sometimes the camera has some awkwark anges when hit by a rocket or mine
- Still early access and room for improvements
- Too easy when you master it
- Menus are not that controller-friendly. The do navigate well with mouse.

This game hearkens back to the glory days of games like Rollcage, Jet Moto and Wipeout; more sci-fi racing games are always a plus in my book.

You control a hulking four wheeled machine with the ability to flip upside down and continue driving (think Tyco Rebound RC). 

You’ll find yourself sticking the walls and ceilings as you blast through tunnels, all the while making lots of mistakes and hitting things. Fortunately the game is fairly forgiving of these mistakes, and you’ll bounce back quickly.

The power ups are fun, but I’d like to see a little more variety in this respect (the game is still in Early Access, so I would not be surprised if we do see more eventually)

I look forward to the release of more content in the form of tracks, cars and hopefully power-ups.

Racing games have sucked lately, people seem to be focusing on realisim over actual fun. Gear switching n stuff like ugh who cares. It's about time we get a combat racer like burnout or vigilante 8.

Oh grip
Jesus H Fuckin Chrst Grip

Racing even with the AI is both intense, fun, difficult and makes you want to play more. Ovbs this aint a game that you will spend your entire life on, but man is it fun.

22052411.review:
[b] Ich habe einen kostenlosen Key für Reviewzwecke bekommen, allerdings beeinflusst dies meine Wertung in keinster Weise. [/b]

[b] KURZREVIEW  [/b]

Ein sehr spaßiger Arcade-Racer mit leider (noch) wenig Content.

[h1] Bugs, Lags aber SPAß! [/h1]

Grip macht sehr viel Spaß, was vor allem an den Items, abwechslungsreichen Maps und toller Musik liegt. Es gibt 2 Fahrzeugsets mit verschiedenen Lakierungen, 3 Maps, von denen 2 noch unfertig sind und einen lokalen Mehrspielermodus. Außerdem kann man vor jedem Rennen verschiedene Sachen einstellen, beispielsweise wie viele Gegner/Runden man haben will, wie viel Power die Motoren haben sollen etc. Es gibt 3 Modi, beispielsweise das normale Rennen und Zeitfahren. Die Performance des Spiels ist schlecht. Auf niedrigen Einstellungen habe ich 30-50F FPS, die allerdings manchmal stark droppen. Zum Vergleich: Project Cars kann ich auf hohen Einstellungen mit 40-60 FPS spielen. Außerdem gibt es ein paar Bugs, manchmal gibt man etwas zu viel Gas und landet neben der Strecke - wieder rein zu kommen kann manchmal etwas dauern und man glitcht sich durch paar Texturen - sollte noch etwas überarbeitet werden. Die Autos fahren sich gut. Bei Updates wird die Review natürlich geupdatet!

[h1] [u] Pro & Contra[/u] [/h1]

+Sehr viel Spaß
+Tolle Items
+Tolle Sounds und Musik
+Abwechslungsreiche Maps
+Optionen vor jedem Rennen

-Kein Onlinemodus
-Zu wenig Content
-Bugs
-Schlechte Performance

[h1] [u] Wertung [/u] [/h1]

[u] Spielspaß: 42/50: [/u]

*Das Spiel macht sehr viel Spaß - Online würde es noch mehr Spaß machen.

[u] Grafik & Design: 16/20 [/u]

*Schöne Grafik und gut designte Maps, die sehr abwechslungsreich sind. Leider schwebt man gelegentlich durch Texturen.

[u] Sound & Musik: 9/10 [/u]

*Super Musik und Sounds

[u] Technik: 2/5 [/u]

*Schlechte Performance und ein paar Bugs

[u] Preis/Leistung: 3/5 [/u]

*Etwas zu wenig Content für den Preis.

[u] Support: 5/5: [/u]

*Entwickler antworten oft im Forum. Monatliche Updates - super! :)

[u] Spieleinstieg: 5/5: [/u]

*Eigentlich ist alles selbsterklärend.

[h1] 82/100 [/h1]

[b] Disclaimer - I have been gifted a free key for this game for review purposes, however my review will be kept as truthful as possible, since I am meant to help developers and buyers/gamers.  [/b] 

[b] GRIP review [/b]

[b] Overview [/b]
"GRIP is futuristic combat racer inspired by the Rollcaage games from 1999/2000." A racing/twisted metal video game Developed by and Published by Caged Element Inc released in early access Feb 2, 2016.

[b] Graphics [/b]
The graphics for an early access game are crazy good, I guess since the graphics become epic,   it would also take a epic good pc to run them on "Epic" as the highest you can go.

[b] Music/Options/Menu [/b]
The music was really cool and pumping adding a nice feel to game like this, The menu was nice and simple easy to get a hang of, And the Options again very nice for a very early access game like GRIP.

[b] Pros and Cons [/b]
Pros:
LOTS of pure potenial
A nice looking racing game with a fun twist
4 modes which all change up the game quite nicely

Cons:
Semi decently optimised
You need a decent pc to run on max graphics
I found a few bugs like falling through the map

[b] Final Rating [/b]

21810622.review:
Beforehand be warned that I am not a native english speaker, I apologize for any mistakes in Spelling or Grammar I made, I still think the following Review should understandable but that is for you to decide.

GRIP, a perfect example how Early Access Games on Steam should work. Since I bought the game with its first Release on Steam the Game changed a lot and this far mostly positive. The Developers listened to feedback from reviews and made changes or additions were they were needed.
In the beginning the Game had some flaws like weird physics, missing map borders and the Tracks were often unclear which lead to difficultys in navigating the vehicles. BUT at the current point these errors are all fixed an the Game is easily playable without encountering any Game Breaking Bugs or vice versa. For the Controls I can't say much about the Controller support because I never played it with one but I can say that it is nice to play on a Keyboard (No sluggish or inaccurate movements when doing so)! One Thing I still wish is that the developers implement mouse support for the Menu and maybe a Setting to enable a free Mousecontrolled Camera while in a Race (but this is also only because I am used to vehicle controlls used in Games like GTA, Watchdogs or the Crew).
The Game just looks stunning in most of its aspects, the Vehicle Models are well made, very detailed and are customizable like you want. Also they done a nice Job on effects of Pickups ecetera. My only complain is that the Game looks sometimes to sharp at edges due to its Anti-Aliasing (Which is a thing that is easily fixed with Postprocessing - in my case Reshade). Also I should mention that I never encountered any Crashes or FPS drops / spikes (even tough I only have 5 Hrs of playtime on record). Currently I don't know what I could also mention instead that I am truly impressed so far by the Progress this Game made. It probably will take quite some time until it is finished completely but it is always nice to just jump in a Rice against NPCs, which are quite challenging in my experience. Also I am excited for the Multiplayer when I finally get to chance to play it with friends. :)

21697498.review:
UPDATE WAS RELEASED TODAY: http://steamcommunity.com/games/396900/announcements/detail/990036254357265305

As such, i will update this review.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

So far, i am loving this game despite playing it only for a few minutes. I haven't been this into a racing game in a long time! 

GRIP is basically a spiritual successor to the popular PS1 and PC classic "Rollcage" (both 1 and 2). If you don't know what Rollcage is, watch this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pXfbo9JPM9U


Pros:

+ Beautiful Graphics (Once again, Unreal Engine 4)

+ Runs very well at a constant 60fps with Vsync on at max settings in 1080p (Specs are on my profile)

+ It's fast, intense, engaging, and consistant. This game FLOWS like no other racer i've played before!

+ Weapon Pickups (This is a combat racer after all)

+ Well done track designs, which offer you some shortcuts to either get ahead, or stay ahead of the game

+ Splitscreen multiplayer. Again, we need more devs to start including this in their games. NOT EVERYTHING HAS TO BE ONLINE ONLY PEOPLE! 

+ Playground mode, which is essentialy a free roam mode

+ Time trial mode (I'm sure you know what this is by now)

+ The floaty controls have been bettered in this new update. Cars drive much nicer now! As a result, i have now moved this to the pros.


Cons:

- Cars STILL bounce easily on even the smallest things. This can also be a bit annoying at first, but it can be funny when you manage to tumble into everyone causing them to tumble and bounce around with you XD

- Still no mid-air control. You cannot steer yourself in the air like most other racers let you do, which can at times get ridiculous when you just cannot stop running into things and bouncing around everywhere

- Arena mode is kinda lacking, but then again this game doesn't have too much to offer at the moment. I'm not surprised, but maybe this'll be more fun with a friend or friends. All you do in this mode is just drive around collecting weapon pickups to destroy all the enemy vehicles.



If they can give us the ability to steer ourselfs mid-flight like a majestic eagle, then this game would be even better! Do i recommend this game?

The answer: OH HELL YEAH! Go buy the game right now, the devs can really use the money to continue supporting and updating the game with new tracks and more! 

I'll update this review as i play more of it.

I played a hell of a lot of Rollcage when I was younger, and this feels exactly as a successor should. I haven't used keyboard controls in GRIP (I use a PS3 controller hooked up via USB & DS3 Tool), and the controls feel great to me. The cars feel like they have real weight to them, which never came across in RC, and the steering and throttle make you feel like sonic on acid. Maybe it's because I spent countless days/months/years in RC, but it's challenging enough to keep it interesting, but easy enough that you can thread the needle at 300mph and feel accomplished.

Of course, it's early access, so there's a lot of tweaks that are needed, but this isn't the place to mention them.
For an early access game, though, the polish on even the least completed course is incredible! Actually, the graphics even for a completed game are amazing.

Get it. Get it now.

21523293.review:
GRIP is fast, furious, fun. Racing in the same league as the likes of Rollcage, F-Zero and Wipeout, GRIP brings futuristic combat racing bang up-to-date.

Unlike in F-Zero and Wipeout, your racecraft sits on four wheels (most of the time), but you can ride up the walls and onto the ceilings of tunnels. The brilliantly designed courses go from narrow winding corridors into wide open spaces that encourage the daring racer to take shortcuts to attain first place. Much like in the aforementioned games there are plenty of pick-ups to grab. Speed boosts, machine guns and rockets litter the course allowing you to gain a timely advantage over your opponents. I love how intense the racing is in this game. Everything can change in a split-second, which is very exciting.

Apart from the standard races and time trials, at time of writing you also get access to 'arena' mode which throws you into a battleground against a number of opponents in a last-man-standing fight to the finish. 'Playground' rounds off the game modes in the current build, which challenges you to find all of the pick-ups on an elaborate testing ground. Even in early access GRIP provides lots to keep you occupied.

Graphically, GRIP looks and sounds great. The maps are vibrant, the craft are colourful, it just looks nice. The soundtrack is the kind of techno that we've heard in other future-racers, and might not be to everyone's taste but the music's not overbearing and fits the theme nicely.

Even in its current early early-access stage GRIP is shaping up very well, and might very well end up being a modern day contender to the brilliant futuristic combat racers of old. Here's a gameplay video:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=frjJNT0vp2I

21433566.review:
Review and Bug Report – Developers, this is for you.  

3 weeks into early access and I’ve picked up this game, played it for over an hour, and I’m gonna start off this review by saying that this isn’t simply a spiritual successor to the Rollcage series. It IS Rollcage 3, whether you want to call it that or not.

Now, let’s get into the actual review. This is based off of playing Time Attack for almost the whole time, and should be treated as such. 

The sense of speed is exhilarating. I never expected to come into it and do well, and I didn’t; the case was the same with the first two games. I crashed a ton of times on every lap, span off or did a 180, drove up the side of walls, left the track boundaries, always struggling to get back on track, and losing a lot of time in the process. But it never feels cheap, nor is it frustrating. When you do screw up, you always know that it’s because that you just couldn’t quite handle the beast that is your vehicle, and that’s great, because Grip – and Rollcage as a whole – is not an easy game/series by any means – this game is [b]hard[/b]. It takes a lot of precision and skill to master handling this four wheeled juggernaut; the smallest mistake can screw you over, but it really is rewarding when you can get it under control. And even if you do crash, drive off or spin off a bunch of times, the game never stops being fun as hell to play. 

***BUG REPORTING STARTS HERE***

Now let’s get onto the bug reporting. As it’s only 3 weeks into early access, I can forgive the fact that the UI and everything except the core game needs a huge amount of work. Still, it needs to be addressed:

Screen resolution options: The resolution sets itself every time I click the arrow to go through the available screen resolution settings. So when I go from 1280x720 to 1280x768, screen flashes to black and then sets to the new res. And this happens for as many different available settings there are: the screen flashes to black no more than a dozen times before I can reach 1080p. We need to be able to click through them all without it auto applying every time: give us an ‘Apply’ button or a dropdown menu, the current system is far too slow. 

Second issue – the res resets itself from 1080p (my selected res) to 720p when I alt tab out and back in, and to make matters worse, there’s no ‘Options’ menu in the Pause menu. So all that time spent clicking through every available resolution to get to the one I need, down the drain. After that I just left it at 720p out of frustration.

The menus can’t be navigated without a mouse – not even the Pause menu. I don’t think the keyboard can be used either. So I can pause the game with my controller (for reference it’s an Xbone controller), but to resume I need the mouse, which requires me to get into an awkward position so that I can left click resume with my left hand while keeping my finger down on the right trigger to accelerate. 

That’s the next issue – upon resuming the game at the Pause menu while holding down the right trigger, it does nothing: I have to release it and press it again to accelerate. 

For some reason I can pause the game after I finish the race and viewing my ‘You placed 1st!’ (Hahaha, me, first…) – This should not be possible. Nor should I be able to pause the game at this point.

Please auto-hide the cursor during gameplay, or when a controller is in use.

The hit boxes for the menu buttons are too small to be clicked with a mouse: the hit boxes should be the same size as the menu buttons themselves. 

On the track Transport, on the planet Liddo 5, the frame rate gets cut in half every time I enter a tunnel, and returns to normal when I exit.

The setup menu needs settings removed from it depending on the game mode currently selected. AI difficulty, number of bots, and number of laps are still included in Time Trial mode, even though there is no AI, and there are unlimited laps. 

****BUG REPORT ENDS****

Despite all of these typical Early Access issues (as is the way with Early Access), for the love of god, buy this game, and support the developers. You won’t regret it, especially considering everything that the team has to offer in the Early Access description. I’ve been waiting for Rollcage 3 for over a decade, and well, here it is. 

I was gonna give this game 22/10 but then the front half of my car got stuck in the ground when I landed after being launched into the air (fix this pls), so I’m gonna take half off and say 11/10, cos the AI names sound like Transformers.

…

Fuck it, one of them is a Transformer and his name is Jetfire.

21433155.review:
Aight so I know all the jokes surrounding games on Early Access, BUT MY GOD, if you ever were or still are a fan of combat racers, you ABSOLUTELY need to play and follow this game, cause it can bring the genre back into its former popularity. The game is only in pre-alpha (only 6 tracks currently, most of which are still under construction), but that alone is already more than just a proof of concept. The fun of GRIP is %50 competition, %50 sensory experience. I prefer to focus on the latter in this review, as I'm sure plenty others will make it a point to address performance/controls/UI (which aren't too shabby imo).

So, GRIP manages to create that rush of high-octane chaos when you launch out of the finish line and you and the other racers are funneled into that first tunnel section; where the boys get sorted from the men. You truly feel the sense of speed as dilapidated sections of blast doors and support columns whip passed you. You feel the weight of your tremendous battle wagon, HAULIN' it down the track. You feel the GRIP of your monstrous tires claw at the ceiling and walls as you ride them like a damn maniac. It is all just that wondrous combination of STEEL and FIRE and GRIT, all going 10fold faster than what you ever thought possible. I hadn't felt these things in a long time, until GRIP FUCKING RIPPED THEM OUT OF ME.

And this is just what the early access pre-alpha dishes out...

So please, pick up this game on early access to support these awesome guys at Caged Element, and give them your feedback if you do, cause they're always looking for input from players on the forum regarding game mechanics, vehicle and track design, etc. We can bring combat racing back.

tl;dr: WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? GET A GRIP, AND GET GRIP.

21348201.review:
Before I even put my opinion out there, I want to give a shout out to FailRace for introducing me to this game in one of his videos.  

Remember those RC cars that could flip over and keep going without issue?  Someone thought "hey let's make a racing game out of this".  Combine some aspects of Mario Kart, F-Zero and Distance, and you got a great game in your hands.  

I have only a few gripes about this, but considering how early it is in development, I can let them slide.
*Air control isn't fast enough.  Not only that, it's really loose and any momentum will make it hard to readjust.
*The tunnels can be disorienting and aren't very stable to drive through at times.  This is more significant in the smaller ones, like on the first track of the first planet.
*It is way too easy to get out of bounds and fall into the void.
*I've had some problems with the front of my car clipping into a wall in the playground area, often getting stuck with no way to reset except to restart the entire session.

21240494.review:
Being that this game is pretty early in early access, there's not a lot of stuff to it at the moment. What it does currently have, though, absolutely reeks of futuristic racing games from the 90s(San Francisco Rush 2049, Extreme-G, Wipeout, etc.), just with a modern day coat of paint. The tracks, the music, the vehicle design, the weapons and power-ups, and the overall vibe add up pretty nicely to something that makes this quite a spiritual successor to the game Rollcage, and a kind of game that we just don't see very often. If you want more than a small handful of areas, vehicles and things like online multiplayer(it has local splitscreen for people with actual irl friends), then you may want to wait a while on buying this. Just note that the price will go up ever so much as the early access program goes on. If however you're fine with it as it is and don't mind the current lack of content, I say go ahead and buy it.

"10/10 Like Wipeout with wheels" -IGN

21220222.review:
[h1]FULL VIDEO REVIEW:[/h1]  https://youtu.be/_cF03cAcI94
[h1]PROS:[/h1][list]
[*]Great sense of speed and a unique verticality to the racing that adds a lot of depth in comparison to traditional Kart racers.
[*]Very faithful to the original Rollcage game.
[*]Satisfying weaponry compounded by the great visuals of the Unreal 4 engine makes the game look good. ~95% 60fps with my GTX770 on all epic settings outside of post processing which murders the framerate.[/list]

[h1]CONS:[/h1][list]
[*]As a Pre-Alpha the game lacks content, no online multiplayer and only 3 race maps, 2 of which are WIP.
[*]Cars slide a bit too easily making it difficult to land after hitting jumps and small bumps.
[*]Track design uses invisible walls a bit too much (mainly in the incomplete maps).
[/list]
Grip is a fantastic pre-alpha, and it makes me excited to see how the game develops through its time in early access. The driving is satisfying, the combat feels brutal, and the current tracks are all both fun to drive on and beautiful to look at. The only real problems I have with the game outside of current lack of content are more of personal preferences and small balance issues that can and will be fixed throughout the development of the game. Once this game gets multiplayer and a few more tracks this will be a definite buy for those looking for a fun, high skill high depth kart racing experience.

21172824.review:
If you like the original Rollcage games, then GRIP certainly is a game for you. If you don't know the concept of Rollcage yet: your car can drive on walls and roofs and it can drive both on its topside and underside. This creates an unique way of racing, because you can continue driving on falls and upside-down jumps. Combine this with various powerups as mines and rockets and you'll have a lot of fun. 

The gameplay of GRIP is already very enjoyable in this early access version. It's combination of racing and weapony provides a high-paced and intense experience. The graphics are great and the up-tempo music really adds to the feeling of speed. With each patch, the tracks are getting better flow and many improvements are made to the physics. Besides normal racing, there are interesting game modes such as time trial, arena (deathmatch), and playground (capture powerups in a sandbox environment) . The powerups such as speed boots, shields, mines, rockets and miniguns are fun and are visually appealing. All in all, all the main elements that you would expect in a combat racer are already there. 

Clearly, there are still downsides that can be expected in an early access version. Multiplayer mode is yet to be implemented. The content is still rather limited with one car and three racing tracks, one of which is heavily work in progress. There is also a noticeable framerate drop when shooting a minigun in some sections. Despite these downsides, you can have a lot of fun with this early access version. 

As final remark, I would like to add that this game has a great development team. The developers are easy to approach and are actively adressing player feedback. This gives the feeling that you are really involved in the development.

21151721.review:
This game is everything I loved about Rollcage.  It doesn't try to be realistic or modern in any way  and despite being currently in Alpha, it runs smoothly on my high end PC and on my average Joe laptop.  The pumping drum and bass, meaty machine guns and beefy explosions are a welcome assault on my ears, leaving the crisp (and sometimes quite trippy) graphics to take care of the visuals and turn my stomache.

And you are guarunteed a few tummy lurchers.  What stood out in Rollcage, was the multi dimensional nature of the gameplay.  Sure, you can stick to the ground in an attempt to indulge in a casual Sunday drive... but why would you when you can pick up a rocket, drive 90 degrees around a banked turn, fire your rocket down on a player on the ground, jump from the vertical bank into a narrow pipe, throw up a little as you lose all sense of direction, fly out the pipe upside-down landing perfectly.

As far as content is concerned, there is just enough to wet the appetite of anyone who took the plunge into the realm of early access.  I completed everything available (bar multiplayer) a couple of times in just under an hour but I'm planning to convice a few friends to pick it up to tackle the multiplayer side.

Thoroughly looking forward to the development of this title!

21137305.review:
TL;DR: It has incredible promise to be Rocket League on steroids. 


For a game that tries so hard to be a 'Distance' reskin, GRIP is an early access that may be hard to recommend. The lack of air control, and steering sens being hard to find, this game is hard to love. There is no sense of "god damn im going fast" other than the engine revving with a deep bass and your tailpipe flaring, but thats only when youre in the last 3 spots and have "catch up" turned on. The tight maps (with the exception of the wide open jungle track thats still in early alpha as of now) are hard to navigate when you do get up to speed or have other racers around you. The collision in the game is made even worse due to the lack of air control or any kind of function to knock other drivers out of the way. If youre going anything above 300mph and hit even the slightest rock or a hair on another racers tire, expect to do go in a random direction with no chance of recevery except resetting your vehicle onto the track.

However...even with all of these flaws, the game has the makings of an incredible release. Since the top hitting racing (car) games are Rocket League and anything involving Grid or Dirt Rally and, as mentioned above, Distance; this brings a refreshing 'grit' to the genre. It has the octane feeling of Rocket League, the cumbersome yet tolerable controls of Grid and Dirt, and the scifi thrill of Distance. I would very highly recommend this game to anyone who wants to jump in early on a game that could potentially be a heavy hitter in the racing scene. It needs improvement, but what early access doest?

21106756.review:
[h1]Это ошеломительно.[/h1]
Ощущается, как будто твоим детством тебе взяли и врезали по морде с громким шлепком. Это [b]тот самый [i]Rollcage 3[/i][/b], о котором я всегда мечтал. Это [b]скорость[/b], от которой звенит в ушах даже после финиша. Это [b]драйв[/b], бьющий по всем болевым точкам нервной системы. Это [b]разрушаемость[/b], о которой только можно было мечтать. Это Unreal Engine 4, благодаря которому всё вокруг выглядит [b][u]потрясающе[/u][/b].

[b]Это он.[/b] Не сомневайтесь.

Хороший выбор автомобилей и отличный набор оружия. Вспоминается то самое чувство, когда первый раз запустил Rollcage, сгонял пару гонок, пришёл во всех из них последним (если вообще доехал до финиша) и радуешься.

На данный момент для меня странным является только то, что "тройкой" (множественные ракеты, выпущенные из переда) нельзя сбить мину.

А так - всё идеально.

Несмотря на статус "раннего доступа" - эта игра стоит того, чтоб её купить и играть в неё.

9/10. Почти доделана.

Обзор актуален на 20.09.2017.

Having played a few races and had a smash about, thought I'd give a quick first impression.
To begin with, if you ever player rollcage, buy this and buy it now. It's similar but a bloody good reboot of the classic and does it justice already and it's in EA.

It's just as challenging as I remember but now you can adjust difficulty to your liking, especially with engine power. Jesus crank it up to just medium and the sense of speed is incredible, but very difficult to control (mostly because you don't want to brake). 
AI isn't f*cking r*tarded either so are strong competitors, there's no online racing mode yet but there's 2 player (I don't have friends so can't comment on this).
Major-ish problem so far is the camera, it makes it real hard to know where you are and what's the floor sometimes, if they made it so the car rotated without the camera doing so while flipping I think it'd improve things (especially if you get motion sickness)

Graphics look good, nice to see TXAA being in there, but of course being early access at high you'll probably get 40-55fps on a sh*t tier mid rig like mine (all AMD, fx6300, R9 270x 4gb), sure this'll be improved later though. Also noticed there's not much difference between fps on low-ultra.
Physics are a bit meh for now but work fine between cars, environments can sometimes eat your car for a few seconds though (luckily there's reset feature). 
Maps are all nice but limited so far, my favourite is the newer one transit, lots of nice winding tunnels to zoom about in, looking forward to more planets and so on. 
There's also only one car type but loads of paint styles, again it runs well and doesn't necessarily need a controller, wads works just fine compared to other racers. 

There's also some nice DnB in the background that suits the game well, although a couple of the songs are really quite repetitive, even for a DnB fanatic like me who's been listening since I was 13. 21060644.review:
EARLY ACCESS EDIT (23rd June 2016):

As of the latest patch, the handling feels much more interesting than it did. It's excellent with a controller, and alright with a keyboard - but I strongly recommend playing with a controller.

I miss the older, lighter, more chaotic handling. However, as it currently stands, there's the potential for a game that's not just a curiosity or a fun pick-up game, but a classic. A few minor annoyances such as snags on invisible parts of the map and what feel like overly-harsh collisions with the force-fields that now form the map boundaries need to be ironed out.

The game would also benefit from some more finished and polished levels that make the *absolute* most of the fun and exciting toolset they've got. The Hard levels they have are great, but some Easy levels that really flow (almost like a good Sonic level, with setpieces and the opportunity to really open up the accelerator) would really help to 'sell' the game to new players.

EARLY ACCESS EDIT (11th February 2016):

As of the latest patch, the nature of the game has changed a little, compared with my initial review. Cars no longer feel like RCs and in general feel weightier and less flighty. It's still fun, but it's less radically old-school than it used to be. With the difficulty as it currently stands, I am able to win races, sometimes easily - I'm not sure how I feel about this as it seems a little odd after so many losses, but the game is definitely still fun. As I mention below, the main adversary is the track/environment. Winning is kind of ancillary to nailing a split-second manoeuvre.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:

GRIP is an incredibly fast-paced spiritual successor to Rollcage.

It's a hugely difficult initial experience because the default difficulty setting is Hard, and it's hard to overcome the instinct instilled in you by most other futuristic or combat-oriented racing games - just hold the accelerator down. If you are having the same difficulties many have had with the game - failing to get beyond 10th place in Hard - simply slow down and don't turn so violently. A gentle touch is required, and contrary to what you might expect, it feels much more stylish to succeed in this fashion than it does to succeed with brute strength and raw speed.

It's nothing like most other racing games, because it doesn't come down to racing lines and subtlety (in the fashion of more realistic racing games), but equally it doesn't rely on ekeing out a lead with raw speed, or even taking out the competition in brutal fashion (as other futuristic 'knockabout' racing games are wont to do). These elements are sort of present, and they'll help to an extent, but they're not the main challenge, and focussing on them will harm more often than it helps. The main challenge primarily comes down to the environment, where hitting a single rock in just the wrong way can completely scupper your chances of victory. In this sense, it has much more in common with old-school games like Micro Machines than it does with its contemporaries, and you'll often feel like you're piloting an RC car in first person.

Unlike many of the other positive reviewers, I sucked at Rollcage and I still suck at GRIP. I struggle to place 7th on the Medium track. And it's still fun! There are so few games where you can get your arse handed to you, repeatedly and thoroughly, and still enjoy the experience. A game where you can accidentally flip upside down from hitting a ramp too hard just as you launch a missile - causing you to spin right into your own missile and take yourself out - is definitely a game where it's fun to lose.

I also recommend Arena mode, which is a lot of fun even against bots.

Multiplayer is currently limited to (correction) two-controller split-screen, so if that's all you're after you'll be disappointed. (see comment for clarification from developer on multiplayer)

20997812.review:
I never played Rollcage, the game this one is a spiritual successor to, but the general concept seems fun and has a lot of potential to me, which is why I decided to pick it up in Early Access. I quickly lost all desire to play after a handful of races. If you're looking into this game, it likely means that you already know what the positives are of the game currently, which is just the core idea behind it (It also looks nice, for what it's worth). Because of that, I'll only be discussing the negatives and why I don't think it's worth spending money on right now for most people.

The handling feels very sensitive to me. It's possible that it's just a thing that takes some time to get used to, but in a game where you need to fit your car into tight spaces and are driving down small corridors, I feel like it screwed me up a few times. Related to that, is the camera, which can shift wildly while your car flips or turns and sometimes lingers in an awkward position, making you feel the need to tilt your head just to keep up. It's unbelievably jarring, and I found myself getting completely lost in tunnels and ending up going the wrong direction by the time I got myself oriented again. The last problem that I have with the game is that it punishes you for being in the air by making landing cleanly very difficult. Very often, your car will lose control once it hits the ground again, which seems like a really poor decision to me in a game that's so arcadey and encourages you to do crazy stuff such as jumping off of ramps.

The game also seems to have some optimization issues and is missing some key features for its options menu, but I don't see these as huge negatives since it is indeed an EA game.

Overall, I found this game to be pretty frustrating, and I think that would be the average gamer's impression of the game if they were to play it in it's current state, which is why it's very hard to recommend at the moment. I'll definitely be keeping an eye on this game in hopes that they make some key changes to the game so that I'll want to buy it again once it officially releases.

20984336.review:
This is a spiritual successor to the "Rollcage" series from the late 1990's/early 2000's, which means that if you liked Rollcage, you'll absolutely love this, and if you've never played Rollcage but like fast-paced combat racers focused on skill, you're at least certain to like this a lot. Think Trackmania mixed with Mariokart mixed with Rocket League, and you pretty much have this series of games, it's challenging, fun, addicting, and generally just really, really good. It's got online multiplayer planned, and unlike most other modern PC games, it also has splitscreen multiplayer available.

I see that some people complain that the game's currently too hard, which is something I disagree with. Like most other racing games, the tracks themselves are bigger foes than your opponents. The difference being that this game, just like it's predecessors, kick this up a notch through a combination of neckbreaking speeds, tunnels, and obstacles that require skill, timing and precision to avoid in an efficient manner, but of course this becomes harder when the racers in front of you plant mines for you and the other competitors to hit, and the ones behind you fire various projectiles your way. It won't hold your hand, and nor should it. It'll be hard when you first start playing, sure, but this only ensures it being a satisfying experience once you've gained the skills required. I will admit that I find the game a bit too easy at the moment, if anything. In it's current state, the AI's pretty stupid and will do many mistakes, and the tracks themselves aren't particularly hard to master either (explained by the fact that only "Easy" and "Medium" difficulty tracks are currently available, with only one of the tracks being relatively finished). One thing to note however is that the controls currently in place adds some difficulty that wasn't present in the older games; the steering feels a bit clumsy and unresponsive, which is something I hope and think will get fixed fairly soon.  

It's also got a really stable technical foundation, beautiful graphics, and great performance, I've tried it on different hardware ranging from a relatively "low-end" gaming system with an AMD A10 7850K coupled with an Nvidia GTX 560, and a "higher-mid-end" system with an Intel i5 4690K coupled with an Nvidia GTX 970, and it runs really well on both, with the latter system running it with max settings in 1920x1080 with ease, making it a gem compared to most other graphically advanced early access titles.

The sound design is also really good, with satisfying 3D effects and feedback, albeit it's suffering from some glitches at the moment (certain explosions and bullet impacts sounding as if they're right next to you, even though they're happening at the other side of the track), but minor quirks like that are to be expected in such an early stage of development, and the developers are working on a fix. 
As long as you like Drum & Base, it's also got an absolutely killer soundtrack. 

The developers are perfect for this game, not only because some of them worked on the previous games, but also because they listen to and interact with the player base, not only on the Steam forums, but on their own forums as well, making sure reported problems get fixed, and popular suggestions get implemented.

I think most of the success about this launch is thanks to the fact that these developers work out of passion. This whole thing started out of love for the original games, and even though their kickstarter campaign failed horribly due to a lack of attention, they still fought on and got it into a working state, as opposed to quite a lot of EA developers out to make a quick buck by catering to popular genres, and then more or less abandoning the project once a satisfiable amount of money has been made.

Oh, and if everything goes according to plan, which I have no doubt it will, we will also get modding tools allowing players to create their own cars and tracks.

So, TL;DR:

+ Fun, addicting gameplay
+ Splitscreen support
+ Great sound design
+ Amazing soundtrack (If you like DnB)
+ The rare combination of good graphics and great performance

20978059.review:
I'm rarely one to purchase Early Access games due to various reasons (I'm sure if you frequent Steam enough, you can put two-and-two together), but while I am very much a lover of the classic Rollcage games, it wasn't that factor alone that persuaded me to support this game.

Now, this IS early access.  There are two full RACES (Yuri Industrial and Wastelands) along with a couple prototype tracks the devs give you to test out.  There are a couple ARENAS (Biodome, an XMAS Map [as of this review] and a test area) as well as a "PLAYGROUND" mode where, well, you just goof around.  

There is only one car, but a good selection of paintjobs to choose from.  You're able to customize how many racers are in the match, how many laps, toggle pick-ups ON/OFF, and set Engine Speeds (think CC in Mario Kart).  Only SOME of the item pick-ups are in the game as of now, but here's where things get good:

Not only are some of the developers those who have originally worked on the RC games from 1999/2000, but they're VERY active in the community and VERY willing to listen to the community's opinions.  They've got specific checklists of suggestions for the games, bugs, what-have-you on their forums, and the updates they've given the game up to now have proven that these devs aren't simply another collective of empty promises.

But this is a review for the game, not of the developers, so here are my personal thoughts on how things are ->AT THIS TIME IN EARLY ACCESS<-.

PROS
- Wonderful Drum 'n Bass OST
- Splitscreen multiplayer
- Controller support
- Graphically, the game is quite pretty (and I have to run it on a lower-res than most)
- Driving 500+KM/h on walls, ceilings, driving loops in tunnels and cars that drive right upside-down or rightside-up.
- Fast-paced combat racing shenanigans you knew and loved in RC (or hopefully will come to love if you're a newcomer).
- The devs listen to feedback and work on that feedback. Hell, even the map-designers and the 3D modelers.
- Arena and Playground modes give you a couple nice-to-have alternatives if you're not in the mood for just racing all the time.

CONS
- As of now, there is only one type of car. (More will be added.)
- A limited selection of tracks. (More will be added.)
- Some people may find the car handling to be difficult at first. (They're actively working out the physics.)
- The collision between cars - and occasionally the environment - is pretty wonky right now.
- You can't rebind your keys or controller settings (it will be implemented).
- No ONLINE Multiplayer (it will be implemented after core gameplay is nailed down).

But I would always recommend that you check out some videos for GRIP to see if the gameplay is your cup of tea before purchasing, keeping in mind that some footage may be outdated (from the private Alpha test) as the changes that come with the patches often come in strides. 

And FYI, you can refund the game as long as you've played for less than two hours courtesy of Steam's refund policy, if it rubs you in all the wrong ways.  So it's a pretty nifty way of getting a "demo" to see for yourself.

20977355.review:
[quote=] I've received a copy for reviewing, yet this hasn't affected my review. [/quote]

[h1] It's finally here...[/h1]

The successor for the PlayStation and PC game, Rollcage, has arrived in full force! The current version gives us on the plate three game modes (Race, Arena, Playground), one car and plenty of stages for now. The single problem I had so far was the lack of control, steering of the car proved to be really difficult and I could not maintain my first place at all, I hope it is going to get fixed as soon as possible for a smoother gameplay, I pretty much felt like a newbie. It is one of the few cons I've found so far in the game, the rest of it is simply divine.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1]

Going onto the game modes, race let us compete against computer controlled cars with some intense combat in the package, basically high speed chasing after the first place with miniguns and missiles. Sad thing is, there's only miniguns, two types of missiles and landmines so far and I'd love some more diversity in the weaponry, but it's early access so they'll probably develop some more in the meantime. While racing gives us a combat for the first place, arena is a merciless carnage where all drivers are put to fight against each other with the mentioned arsenal at disposition along with a speed boost and shield (They are also in the race mode, do not fret) powerup. Then, comes the playground mode where it pits the player to find all the 42 packages on a map that looks like a construction site but also gives us a few hints as of what destruction to expect later on (In the site map you can destroy walls, pillars) yet I ran into the problem that if you crash into certain places and get stuck you can't respawn but to exit and restart it from the start.

[h1] Graphics [/h1]

The stages are pure eye candy, just stunning and extremely detailed even for the ones that are prototypes. They all have a different setting which makes them unique but, there's something that bugs me and those are the barricades in the tunnels which are really easy to hit and can make you fall down in the leaderboard to the last place quite fast.

[h1] OST & SFX [/h1]

The soundtrack? Drum and bass is enough for an eargasm and some chills down the spine as you destroy your way to the first place!

[h1] Should you buy it? [/h1]

Grip is already a masterpiece and has met my expectations. You should buy it as soon as possible, because this is a gem that shouldn't be missing from your game collection and its the best experience you can get for this price.

[quote=] If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation] Original Curator Group [/url] [/quote]

20968824.review:
No encuentro ningún análisis en español, así que ahí va esa.

Desde que jugué a Rollcage y Rollcage Stage 2 hará ya como 17 años, me impactó gratamente. Solía jugarlo a todas horas, dibuja sus coches, pistas y momentos.
Conforme fuí creciendo, entrando mucho más en el mundo de los juegos y su desarrollo, buscaba y buscaba remakes, mods y de todo sobre Rollcage. Incluso pensé en desarrollar algo yo mismo, y casi que fue de lo primero que me metió en el mundo del desarrollo.

Cada cierta cantidad de tiempo, volvía a buscar y a buscar, esperando encontrar algo.

Y hace no mucho tiempo, apareció GRIP en Kickstarter, (Oh, rejoice), y obviamente lanzé dinero como un poseso.

Tristemente fallaron, y sí, me sentí algo devastado. Pero no se rindieron y siguieron su propia manera de funding.

Y ahora, el juego esta en manos de todos, en Steam.

Así que ¿Qué decir de GRIP?

Velocidad, combate, dificultad, promesa... A parte de los desarrolladores más atentos que he visto en mucho tiempo. (Sólo hay que echar un vistazo a los foros oficiales para darse cuenta de lo implicados que están.)

GRIP es lo que llevabamos esperando muchos años (muchisimos).

Ahora mismo es MUY Alpha, pero se mantiene, nada de crashes, rendimiento perfecto, buen detalle gráfico, controles, interfaz... Básicamente, en el poco contenido que tiene, nunca sentirás que el juego está "mal hecho".

Con la promesa de muchos más coches, personalización en estos, pistas, modo liga, multiplayer online (Ya tiene un local para dos jugadores muy sólido) y mucho más, prometiendo actualizaciones hasta bien entrado 2017. Es un juego que necesitas jugar, tanto si eras fan de los originales Rollcage, como si te gustan los arcades de conducción como Wipeout, F-Zero o incluso Mario Kart (Tenemos una versión del caparazón azul excelente)

TL;DR: Por 15,99€, muchas promesas y desarrolladores atentos, no tienes nada que perder en absoluto para disfrutor este arcade de conducción.

20955560.review:
GRIP is pretty cool!  We need more of these combat racers.  The graphics engine used is perfect, Unreal 4 does a great job here.  For an early-stage alpha, it shows great promise.

The problem is that I think the controls are a little sluggish.  I can notice at least a 0.25s input lag on every turn of the joystick.  It made it difficult to play, to be honest.  I'm normally very good at racing games, but this game made me feel like I had never played a racer before.  Each time I had to avoid an object, it was like I pressed the controls too late.  Even on easy mode, with the rubberband "catch up" mode enabled, I can barely avoid make last place in a race.  It's actually almost impossible for me, and when I compare my reaction times with something face paced like Race The Sun, this game feels like there is an old grandma at the wheel.  PLEASE make the turning reaction quicker!  

There are only a few modes right now; racing, arena, and playground.  Racing I found too difficult due to lag, and that leaves arena as a focus point.  Well, there are machine guns and rocket launchers.  It's very ordinary.  We need many, many more weapons to make it interesting.  But it's a good start.  Playground could be fun, but there's only one map right now, they should let us explore the racing maps and arena maps too.  In the one "construction" map, there is some fun to be had here, but a problem I had is that you cannot respawn.  If you get stuck, you need to exit and enter the map again.  There are 42 packages to find in the playground map, but you need to find them all before you get stuck somewhere, as every time you reload the map you need to start over.  Lame!  Let us just find all 42 packages once, or at least remember which ones we previously found, otherwise it's not an easter egg hunt anymore.  A fix for this would be to make the respawn button just respawn us at the beginning of the map.  Also, in playground mode there is some excellent examples of map destruction (walls to destroy, pillars) which I suppose are previews of what to expect later.  These are really cool.  But for some reason you can't play local co-op in playground mode.  This would have been the most fun!!!

The map design for the races are done very well.  There are only a couple that do not have "VERY EARLY ALPHA PROTOTYPE" plastered all over the thumbnails, but to be honest they are all very good.  It was never the maps that threw me off, and they are all very unique and well though out.  Except that one where you go through tunnels and have to somehow fit in a pathway that is the width of the car.  Please remove or limit the size of these little barriers.  I have never been able to make it through that gap.  It's a problem.  Especially with how sluggish the controls are.

So overall, the game is very hard to recommend.  However it IS an early access alpha, and it looks great.  It feels right, but not tight.  It's just in need of a few more maps and weapons before it's ready.  The hard part is done, now they just need to finish it.  I'm really looking forward to seeing patches for this game come rolling down the pipeline and to watch it progress.

20949666.review:
Here is a review of the game, from my viewpoint, as of EAbuild1.0.6.

The handling has undergone some massive changes since 1.0.4, and is doing amazingly well. Take a gender through the forums to understand why these beasts are suppossed to slew around after a sideways landing, they're freaking HUGE.

The weapons are as volatile and crazy as weapons should be. Never trust a rocket to go forwards if you're not facing forwards. That's what makes the way this game is being built so good, attention is being paid to all appropriate aspects.

The music is VERY good. Different from Rollcage (I don't think anything can beat Doubelcross by the ever prevalent E-Z Rollers) but very much in fitting with the game.

But the best bit of the game so far, is how everything works together. Yes, the driving mechanics will probably get tweaked a hundred times through development. Yes, the weapons will turn into pink unicorns at some point, just to see what happens. And yes, things are going to break, and be buggy, and just refuse to drive around obstacles...

But that's what's so great. All these bugs help shape the game naturally. It can actually develop, and not just be bashed together. It can be continuously tweaked, and refined, and purified until it is the best combat racer for a long time. 

Because, at the end of the day, what makes the game great is how great it is to play. The feeling of the guns, the rockets, the way you can feel the car sliding, even though you're holding a controller and sitting on your couch at home. The way that you literally scream at your screen when an opponent smacks you in the face with a rocket, or tickles you from behind with the machine gun. It takes you back to the quintessential point of a combat racer. Driving fast, driving hard, and being angrier than everyone else on the track.

Suffice to say, I really like this game. And I cannot imagine how good it will be when it's finished.

Игра развивается стремительнейшим образом. Автопарк уже достаточно объемный и на любой вкус. И даже можно "прокачивать" болид. Треков накидали тоже уже приличную пачку. Игра более чем стоит покупки, сообенно теперь - есть во что играть, и цена еще не сильно поднялась (после полноценного релиза обещают прилично поднять)

20945020.review:
If you played Rollcage (Deathtrack Racing) or Rollcage Stage 2 on the PS1 or PC, this game should be on your radar.
If you like dirty, filthy drum and bass, this game should be on your radar.
If you are interested in the idea of driving on the ceiling firing a chaingun or missiles at other racers in flippable cars that weigh tonnes at upwards of 400kph, this should be on your radar.
If you enjoy noisy, speedy, action-packed fun, see above.

The developers are actively updating and listening to the players, yes, it's early access, but it holds genuine pedigree, former Attention To Detail (Rollcage, Rollcage S2) developers are in the development team and they have been working constantly with meaty updates, it keeps getting better.
Multiplayer currently has split-screen mode, online will be coming later.
The cars feel weighty, weapons have that carthatic sensation, the music bangs away nicely.
Recommended, even in early access.

20942858.review:
My review is based on the following version: Pre-Alpha Early Access v1.0.6.0

I haven't played all that much of the game yet, but what I've played was fantastic! First things first: GRIP definitely has the "Early Access feel" to it. There currently is only one proper vehicle (though in several color variations), there are not that many tracks yet, my controller doesn't work in the menus and it's a pain to change some settings like resolution. There are also some glitches and bugs I've experienced, plus the physics and collisions don't always feel on point. Yes, this is in Early Access and very much feels like it, so those of you who want an absolutely polished, content-rich game should probably wait out.

Now on to the things GRIP has in store and already makes right - it is ridiculously fun and addictive! I never played the original Roll Cage, but I quickly fell in love with the concept. It's mad fun driving on the walls and on the ceiling and makes for a very dynamic gameplay. The controls, while a little tricky at first, feel tight. Just as tricky can be the car's behaviour on ramps and during landings playing it for the first time, but it's easy to get used to the physics. The sense of speed is in full effect, though it rarely feels like actually driving 400+ km/h ;) Still a fantastic feeling to drive past all opponents when the nitrous pickup kicks in! Speaking of pickups: The current selection of pickups offers the typical variants that I expect from such a car combat game. Nitrous, mines, shields, short-range miniguns as well as chasing rockets. Each pickup can help tremendously when used right, but also be wasted when the usage is timed badly. A great feature that compliments the pickup weapons well is the function to manually activate slow-motion. You can pull off very cinematic sequences with enemies losing control because of you shooting at him, causing him to drive up a rock, spinning uncontrollably in the air - all in awesome slo-mo! The game does a good job at presenting all the action that is caused by the sly tracks, by the use of pickups and by the AI drivers. I quite like all of the three AI presets that this game has to offer. But GRIP is tense even on the easiest difficulty, as a simple screwup or a well timed hit by an enemy in the last section of a track usually results in losing several spots.

Let's talk about content, that is not too shabby considering the EA state. There are three game modes available that contain different maps and tracks. Race is my favorite and currently contains three tracks. Two of those are more or less finished as far as I can tell, with the third one being in an early work in progress state - still being lots of fun already though. Players have several options to setup the action on the tracks. Along with the difficulty setting there are options to disable pickups, to configure the number of laps (2,4 or 8) and the number of combatants (6,8 or 10). On top of that, the engine power can experimentally be raised and a catch-up assist can be enabled. I really like this option for a rubberbanding AI, as it can be easy to mess up and loose the opponents. This option helps catching up on the enemies to ensure a tense race. Arena has all the same options and sees all the combatants trying to damage and eventually frag each other. Once again, there are three levels ready, with one being an experimental early build. Both Arena and Race seem to ultimately get 12 tracks each, which I would be totally fine with. I'm having so much fun on every single one of the available maps that I'm sure that the others will be equally great. Next up is the mode Playground, that has the player collect some orbs spread across a huge, you guessed it, playground and just mess around with the vehicle and lots of ramps and walls. The devs apparently want this mode to have three playgrounds, with one already available. Greyed out for now is the Time Trial mode, which I guess will pretty much be Race without the opponents. Not there yet but hinted at already is "Grip League". As the devs want to add online functionality with a future update, I figure this will be a competititve online league. Lastly, there already is a splitscreen mode for two players in place with the same modes and options as in solo play, minus Playground. Great fun for some couch competitiveness, with four player splitscreen already announced as well. So all in all, I wouldn't call the content sparse, though it's also not packed with lots of vehicles and tracks...yet. The content as of today is solid for EA and there are many great things in prospect.

The soundtrack consists of some great Drum'n'Bass tunes that fit amazingly well to the action and always get me pumped. Graphically, it looks pretty good. Even though the early version tracks might look a little barren, the game overall looks good in motion. I'd even call it pretty on the most barebone graphical settings. It has a decent amount of settings in this department, ranging from FXAA and TXAA as Anti-Aliasing solutions to object quality, effects, shadow, post process and texture quality settings. Playing on a R9 390, I5 6600K, 8GB RAM at 1440p, I use most settings at their highest choice and get a decent performance that sits well above 60 FPS for most of the time. I feel that the higher effects settings cost a lot of performance, so I leave that on Low and it still looks really good. Performance is pretty consistent, though the game might dip when lots of opponents are on screen next to explosions. With my slightly lowered settings, I keep the dips at a small pace though. Once again, considering the EA state, I'm impressed with both the looks and the performance.

[b]I absolutely love what I've played so far and immediately wanna get back into the combat madness! The main concept is brilliant and well executed. The content is okay-ish, with much more on the horizon though. There are some smaller issues that still scream "Early Access", but nothing that really comes in the way of having fun. If you are even slightly interested in what you are seeing and fine with content being gradually rolled out, go for it! Now! And thank me later :)[/b]

Jau dann möcht ich doch auch malwieder meinen Senf dazugeben!

Ich hatte das Spiel seit der Greenlighteinsendung im Auge und konnte es bis Release auf Steam kaum erwarten weil ich Rollcage damals sehr mochte, also ging da kein Weg dran vorbei!

Das Spiel befindet sich im sehr frphen Anfangsstadium was den Inhalt betrifft ist aber technisch einwanfrei gelungen!

Keine Ruckler, Frameeinbrüche oder der gleichen, der Sound und die Optik sind Top, Glasklar und alles passt perfekt zusammen! Momentan (3. Februar 2015) beinhaltet das Spiel 2 Planeten mit insgesammt 3 Strecken, 2 davon sind Under Construction, lassen sich aber sehr Gut spielen! Diese darf man mit einem Battlecar fahren welches mit 12 unterschiedlichen Farben gefahren werden darf!

Man kann das Spiel mit diversen Setups vorher bearbeiten wie der geschwindigkeit oder so sachen wie Anzah der Gegner oder einen CatchUp Assistenten um die Perks besser aufsammeln zu können!

20935558.review:
There are plenty of reviews out there which focus on the game, so I'll focus mine on the devs.

Between the game's private beta and the public release on Steam, it has been updated numerous times already. Not just adding features along the way, but also implementing user feedback (ranging from bug reports to game suggestions) from the community. They devs are super approachable, but stay true to the game and their vision.
This isn't EA reviving an old franchise to churn out shit. This is [b]cool dudes making a cool game: we actually care edition[/b].

Even so, that's not enough. I'll tell you why I have faith in this project, despite it's early access status:

Rob spent a lot of his free time to update the PC port of Rollcage, 15 years after it's initial release, to please old fanboys who couldn't let go of the game. I'm talking rewriting the rendering engine, rewriting of the audio engine, rewriting of the networking system, all to make it work better on modern operating systems.
Now he's working on GRIP, earning less than he would have working a regular job, but he's doing it out of love.

David is another one of those blokes who worked on the original Rollcage games. Obviously he's not nearly as amazing as Rob, but this guy went dumpsterdiving (in his attic) and dug out some sweet nostalgia from the Rollcage developing-days for us to gaze at.
Also, this man made a few of the Rollcage tracks many have grown to love (or hate) and was the producer of Stage II. Dude's an expert on making you feel good. He made me feel good and I want him to do it again.

Chris is the one who got the project started and he's cool as a cucumber. He knows that if he messes up in any way, people will come to stalk him in Canada.
Luckily, for his own sake, he hasn't messed up yet and actually gives the impression that he 'gets' what people want/like.
Probably has something to do with him being a fan of the Rollcage games as well.

There are quite a few more helping hands behind the scenes, but I honestly haven't communicated with them all that much yet.
([url=http://forum.cagedelement.com/viewtopic.php?f=3&t=340]Despite it being super easy[/url]).
Either way, this game is in good hands.

20930613.review:
Grip weckt bei mir so einige Kindheitserinnerungen von RC Autos und einem Videospiel, dass ich von der PS1 kenne!

Allgemein: GRIP ist ein sehr schönes Spiel, die Grafik ist sehr gut und verbraucht wirklich nicht viele Ressourcen, was meiner Meinung nach immer schön an einem Spiel ist. Die Strecken sind perfekt und bieten immer Möglichkeiten für Abkürzungen oder coole Tunnel in denen man die Wände hoch fahren kann.

Gameplay:
Es ist schon ein sehr Actiogeladenes Spiel. Es ermöglicht das Fahren an Wänden oder Decken und bietet auch den Abschuss, oder Schutz durch Power-ups. Das besondere ist sicherlich, dass Autos keine wirkliche Oberseite besitzen. Vielmehr können sie auf beiden Seiten fahren, daher ist eine Fassrolle kein Problem sollte man den Abschluss nicht hinkriegen bei einer Rampe oder gar von einem Mitspieler umgestoßen werden. Die Power-Ups sind die üblichen bekannten, die man schon aus anderen Arcaderacern kennt.

Mankos:
Die Menüführung mit dem Controller ist noch sehr schwer und vorallem extrem unübersichtlicht. Während man bei einem mouseover den effekt bekommt, dass sich der Menüpunkt orange färbt, ist beim Controller nur eine leichte kaum sehbare weiße gestrichelte Linie (Bei Weißen Buttons!!)

Fazit:

Hat sehr viel Potenzial das Spiel freue mich schon auf mehr von den Entwicklern nur weiter so! Ich würde es sicherlich empfehlen auch wenn es ein Early Access ist und dadurch aktuell nur das Offline Spiel oder der 2 Spieler Modus zur verfügung stehen.

20929629.review:
I recommend this game for everyone, especially those who played Rollcage in their childhood, whether it was on PC or PlayStation 1.

This game as it is stated for now, is still in early access, but don't back off yet. It's not just an ordinary unfinished product with lazy developers who will leave it unfinished. 

Community on forum and steam group is alive as any other. Developers always talk to us and gives constant updates on the situation. There are already tons of topics and ideas for upcoming content and If you like racing games such as Motorstorm: Apocalypse, Wipeout or even F-Zero. You will definitely like this one. About graphics, It Runs on Unreal Engine 4 and it looks very beautiful (it looks like an AAA title)

This game is constantly under development, the career mode with story will be added later, the physics of cars will change and full version will have connection with workshop. You will be able to import your own content into the game. (hopefully)

There is lot more to talk about, but basically this is what is GRiP as for today. Be patient though, as it will get only better, and I can fully recommend this game from bottom of my heart. Community and developers are kind, and the game is really there with each update. Spiritual successor at its finest.

[b]Zum Spiel:[/b]

Ja es ist Rollcage mit Leib und Seele und es fühlt sich genau so an wie früher.
Der Umfang ist zum Start des Early Access noch sehr gering. So gibt es bisher nur 2 Planeten mit insgesamt 3 fahrbaren Strecken. Einen Arena Modus mit 2 Arenen und eine Stunt Arena in der es gilt alle Pickups aufzusammeln.Hier kann man sich auch mit dem Fahrverhalten seines Boliden vertraut machen.

Frustresistenz sollte man auch mitbringen,denn das Spiel ist auch auf leichtem Schwierigkeitsgrad sehr schwer zu meistern,was natürlich auch mit dem Fahrverhalten eures Wagens zu tun hat.Die teilweise engen Schluchten und unwegsamen Streckenabschnitte lassen euch des öfteren mal komplett unkontrolliert abfliegen,wenn man nicht mal vom Gas geht.
Die Geschwindigkeit ist enorm und lässt einen schweißnasse Hände bekommen,wenn man dann noch einen der vorderen Ränge belegt,wird man nur so von Raketen gejagt.

Online Multiplayer ist noch nicht mit integriert,soll aber kommen.Derweil ist nur ein 2 Player Splitscreen Rennen verfügbar.

Wer auf treibende Drum n´ Bass Tracks steht,bekommt hier mächtig was auf die Ohren.

Trotz geringem Umfang der jetzigen E/A Version,kann ich das Spiel jetzt schon empfehlen.Es macht unglaublich viel Spass über die Pisten zu brettern.Von mir einen Daumen nach oben!

20921906.review:
My first review written was at launch and its been a year and a half since then so its time for an update. GRIP has only gotten better since launch. Now boasting new content mulitplayer, and overall better performance. It still retains fast paced racing with car combat but now with more cars and tracks to choose from and as of a recent update since this review, a new weapon. It can be compared to rollcage but it created its own identiy in the development process boasting larger tracks and different but better driving physics. The cars in the game feel different enough where they require a slightly similar driving style either requiring more braking or focusing on shortcuts and boost pannels. Tracks vary from easy, big, and open to hard, thin and rollercoaster like. One thing all tracks have in common is multiple paths to race on all with their perks and downsides. Weapons generally feel good but missiles require a little strategy to use. 

TL:DR
Very good car combat racer that still has some more content to come.
